Choose the correct code:(UGC NET Management Aug 2016)Statement – I: Decide on the nature and amounts of incentives to be paid to subordinates is a department supervisor’s (line) activity.Statement – II:Conducting job evaluation procedures aimed at determining relative worth of each job in the organization is a HR Specialists’ (staff) activity.
  • A.Both I and II are correct.
  • B.Both I and II are incorrect.
  • C.Only I is correct.
  • D.Only II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both I and II are correct.

Both I and II are correct.

 

Statement I:

The primary difference between the line and staff functions is accountability. Line managers are directly responsible for achievement of target oriented jobs that form the core of the business’s existence, such as sales or production. The staff function governs advisory services that impact the efficacy of the line function but do not directly take part in the production planning and marketing.

Departments such as manufacturing and sales have been described as performing "line function", while departments such as purchasing, accounting, advertising, personnel, plant maintenance, and quality control have been described as performing "staff functions".

 

Statement II:

Job Evaluation is a systematic process of determining the relative worth of jobs to establish which jobs should be paid more than others within an organization. It is a method used to describe, analyse, compare and evaluate jobs within a unit, a branch, or an industry on the basis of the work content and the job requirements in order to place them under particular wage or salary grades. It has two basic objectives: 

a. To compare jobs and determine their level within each occupational group; and 

b. To compare jobs between occupational groups.

Question 10
Giving employees more authority is known as: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)
  • A.Authority
  • B.Responsibility
  • C.Employee Empowerment
  • D.Decentralization
Correct Answer: Employee Empowerment

Giving employees more authority is known as Employee Empowerment. It is defined as the ways in which organizations provide their employees with a certain degree of autonomy and control in their day-to-day activities. This can include having a voice in process improvement, helping to create and manage new systems and tactics, and running smaller departments with less oversight from higher-level management.

 

A key principle of employee empowerment is providing employees the means for making important decisions and helping ensure those decisions are correct. When deployed properly, this should result in heightened productivity and a better quality of employee work and work life.

 

The other concepts given in the question are also defined below:

 

Henry Fayol defined authority as the right to give orders and the power to exact obedience. Thus, authority is the legitimate right to command or influence others to behave toward the attainment of specific goals of an administrative system.

 

Responsibility is the obligation to carry out certain duties. It has an inseparable relationship with authority. Without authority it is not possible to take up responsibility. An administrator, while giving authority to his subordinates should also make them responsible. For exercising authority judiciously and purposefully.

 

Decentralisation is referred to as a form of an organisational structure where there is the delegation of authority by the top management to the middle and lower levels of management in an organisation.

Question 11
Which one of the following is NOT associated with authority? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.Right to issue directions
  • B.Obligation to perform the assigned tasks
  • C.Delegated from supervisor to subordinates
  • D.Flows from top to bottom
Correct Answer: Obligation to perform the assigned tasks

Authority indeed revolves around the right to issue directives, delegation from higher to lower levels, and the hierarchical flow within an organization. "Obligation to perform assigned tasks" aligns more with the notion of responsibility, emphasizing the duties and tasks individuals are accountable for carrying out.

Question 12
The right delegated to an individual or a department to control specified processes, practices, policies or other matters relating to activities undertaken by persons in other departments is called: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.Delegation of power
  • B.Centralization of power
  • C.Empowerment of employees
  • D.Functional authority delegation
Correct Answer: Functional authority delegation

Delegation of Power – It is the process that transfers authority from senior to a subordinate and allows a subordinate to exercise his discretion in making certain decisions.  Since top level management is mainly concerned with strategic decision making, it becomes necessary for the top-level executives to delegate their powers to their subordinate for routine tasks.

 

Centralization of Power – It is the process by which the activities of the organization, particularly those regarding planning and decision making, become concentrated within a particular geographical location group. It also refers to the systematic and consistent concentration of authority at a central point or in a person within the organization.

 

Empowerment of Employees – It the process of giving employees a certain degree of autonomy and responsibility for decision-making regarding their specific organizational tasks. It allows decisions to be made at the lower levels of an organization where employees have a unique view of the issues and problems facing the organization at a certain level.

 

Functional Authority Delegation – In an organization, some specified processes or functions of the organization such as finance, marketing, PR etc. are divided and for each such tasks, specialists or functional heads are appointed to perform the related task.  Each functional area is put under the charge of functional specialists and he has got the authority to give all decisions regarding the function whenever the function is performed throughout the enterprise. Expert knowledge of functional manager facilitates better control and supervision along with specialization.

Question 13
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)Statement I:Delegation is an interpersonal transaction based on behavior analysis.Statement II:Delegation is an evolutionary and developmental process that needs encouragement and reinforcement.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.StatementI is incorrect but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: StatementI is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

Statement II touches upon the core essence of delegation. Delegation is indeed an evolutionary and developmental process within an organization. It involves assigning tasks or responsibilities from a superior to a subordinate while providing the necessary authority to accomplish those tasks. This process evolves over time and often requires encouragement, reinforcement, and nurturing to enhance the delegation process effectively. It's about nurturing trust, empowering individuals, and fostering growth.

 

However, Statement I's assertion that delegation is solely an interpersonal transaction based on behavior analysis might be limiting. Delegation involves not just interpersonal interactions but also includes aspects of authority, responsibility, accountability, and organizational structure. While behavior analysis can be a part of understanding delegation, it's not the sole defining factor. Delegation is a multifaceted process that involves various elements beyond interpersonal behavior analysis. Therefore, considering delegation as solely based on behavior analysis might not provide a comprehensive understanding.

Question 14
Match List I with List II:[UGC NET Management June 2021]List Ia. Simple structureb. Functional structurec. Team structured. Learning organization structureList IIi. A structure that supports an organization's capacity to continuously adapt and changeii. A structure in which the entire organization is made up of workgroupsiii. It is an organizational design that groups similar occupational specialties togetheriv. It is an organizational design with low departmentalization, wide span of control and little formalizationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • D.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

The correct answer is (A) a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i.

 

a. Simple structure: It is an organizational design with low departmentalization, wide span of control and little formalization. 

b. Functional structure: It is an organizational design that groups similar occupational specialties together. 

c. Team structure: A structure in which the entire organization is made up of workgroups.

d. Learning organization structure: A structure that supports an organization's capacity to continuously adapt and change.

Question 15
Authority is the right to make decisions to direct the work of others and to give orders. In this context match List-I with List-II:[UGC NET Management June 2019]List-I(a) Line Authority(b) Staff Authority(c) Line Manager(d) Staff ManagerList-II(i) Gives a manager the right to advice other managers or employees(ii) Traditionally gives managers the right to issue orders to other managers or employees(iii) A manager who assists and advises the manager(iv) A manager who is authorised to direct the work of subordinates is responsible for accomplishing the organisation's tasksChoose the correct option from those given below:
  • A.(a)-(i);(b)-(iv);(c)-(iii);(d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(ii); (b)-(i); (c)-(iv); (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(ii); (c)-(iii); (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(ii); (b)-(iii); (c)-(i); (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii); (b)-(i); (c)-(iv); (d)-(iii)

The correct answer is (B) (a)-(ii); (b)-(i); (c)-(iv); (d)-(iii).

 

Line Authority refers to the traditional power that a manager possesses to issue direct commands and instructions to employees or other managers within their area of responsibility. This authority flows down from higher levels of management to those directly involved in accomplishing the core tasks of the organization. A manager exercising line authority is a Line Manager, responsible for overseeing and ensuring the completion of specific organizational objectives.

 

Staff Authority, on the other hand, involves providing advice, guidance, and support to line managers or employees. Staff managers typically assist and advise line managers, offering specialized knowledge or expertise that helps in decision-making or executing tasks efficiently. They have the authority to offer guidance and recommendations but don't possess direct control over the implementation of tasks.

Question 16
Which one of the following is NOT true for the functional organization? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.It is based on the principle of unity of command
  • B.The discipline tends to become loose
  • C.It is useful for large‐scale business
  • D.Functional managers are specialists in their respective areas
Correct Answer: It is based on the principle of unity of command

Unity of command, which emphasizes that an employee should report to only one superior to avoid confusion and conflicting directives, is a principle most closely associated with traditional hierarchical organizational structures, such as line structures, rather than functional structures.

 

In functional structures, employees are grouped based on their specialized skills or functions they perform, such as HR, finance, marketing, etc. Therefore, the principle of unity of command may not be as strictly adhered to in a functional structure, as individuals might report to a functional manager within their area of expertise but could still receive directives from various other managers based on cross-functional requirements or projects.

 

Hence, option (A) is incorrect because unity of command is not necessarily a defining feature of a functional organization.

Question 17
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List Ia. Learning organizationb. Spaghetti organizationc. Fishnet organisationd. Network structureList IIi. Flexibility in the structure or lack of structure.ii. Linking of separate parts of the same organization or networking of separate organizations to accomplish a common goal.iii. The ability to continually change structure and internal process to conform to feedback with the environment.iv. Flexible, adaptable, rearranges itself quickly while retaining its inherent strength.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-i, b-iv, c-iii, d-ii
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Option B is the correct answer.

 

A learning organization is a company that facilitates the learning of its members and continuously transforms itself. The concept was coined through the work and research of Peter Senge and his colleagues.

 

Spaghetti Organization refers to a flat, loosely coupled, project-based organization characterized by ambiguous job boundaries and extensive delegation of task and project responsibilities to autonomous teams.

 

The fishnet organizations are flexible; it can form and reform, it rearranges itself quickly while retaining its inherent strength. This was quoted by Johansen & Swigart.

 

Network organization structure aims at linking of separate parts of the same organization or networking of separate organizations to accomplish a common goal.

Question 18
Which among the following is NOT a primary determinant of organizational structure?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Chain and span
  • B.Capacity and lower needs
  • C.Power and control
  • D.Differentiation and integration
Correct Answer: Capacity and lower needs

Option B is the correct answer. Capacity and lower needs are not the determinants of organizational structure.

 

An organizational structure is a system that outlines how certain activities are directed in order to achieve the goals of an organization. These activities can include rules, roles, and responsibilities.

 

Chain of command refers to the levels of authority in a company 

 

Span of control is the number of subordinates a manager is responsible for controlling.

Question 19
Match List I with List II. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)List II. Ad-hoc team formed to solve unusual problemII. Suitable when there are large numbers of small projectsIII. Status-free and hierarchy-free organizationIV. Digital or dot com organizationList II1. Virtual organization2. Task force3. Free form organization4. Matrix organizationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I-3, II-1, III-4, IV-2
  • B.I-1, II-2, III-4, IV-3
  • C.I-2, II-4, III-3, IV-1
  • D.I-4, II-1, III-2, IV-3
Correct Answer: I-2, II-4, III-3, IV-1

Ad-hoc team formed to solve unusual problem: Committee Organization and Task Force

The distinguishing feature of a committee organization is that there is a committee for a particular function or department. For example, instead of a marketing manager, there may be marketing committee for marketing activities, The Committee is also known by other names like commission, task force, quality circle, board etc. The Committee is always a group of people.

An ad hoc committee for a specific purpose and time period is called "task force".

  

Suitable when there are large numbers of small projects: Matrix Organization

An example of Matrix structure is where its groups employees by both function and product. This structure can combine the best of both separate structures. An example would be a company that produces two products, "product I" and "product II". Using the matrix structure, this company would organize functions within the company as follows: "product I" sales department, "product I" customer service department, "product I" accounting, "product II" sales department, "product II" customer service department, "product II" accounting department. Matrix structure is the most complex of the different organizational structures.

 

The main difference between project and matrix organization is that a project organization is suitable for smaller number of large projects while the matrix organization is suitable for large number of smaller projects.

 

Status-free and hierarchy-free organization: Free Form Organization

It is a special type of team-based organization without organizational hierarchy and boss-subordinate positions that can successfully operate with greater degree of flexibility, speed, and adaptability in a highly dynamic environment. It is also called naturalistic, organic, and ad hoc form of organization.

 

Digital or dot com organization: Virtual Organization

They are also known as digital or dotcom organizations. They are nothing but Network Organizations with power of Information Technology. Virtual organization can be defined as a network made up of companies, clients, customers and employees who link themselves via internet technologies for business purposes. 

Question 20
Which of the following is not correct with respect to matrix organisation? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.It is the combination of fundamental and product organisation
  • B.Functional departments are not permanent fixtures of a matrix organisation
  • C.Product departments are created as the need for them arises
  • D.Team members have functional home when they are not needed on a project
Correct Answer: Functional departments are not permanent fixtures of a matrix organisation

Statement B is not correct with respect to matrix organisation. 

 

According to Fred Luthans “Matrix organisation represents a combination of functional department organisation and project organisation”. The features of matrix organisation are as follows:

 

1. A matrix organisation is a structure in which there is more than one line of reporting managers. Effectively, it means that the employees of the organisation have more than one boss. 

 

2. When an enterprise undertakes a large number of small projects, a matrix organisation is formed with a dual line of command.

 

3. In Matrix organisation a project structure is imposed over the permanent functional structure of the organisation and members of the project team being subject to a dual line of command (that of the project manager and the concerned functional specialist whose department they originally belong to) forming a matrix or grid. 

 

4. Under a matrix organisation project teams are formed; drawing personnel from the permanent functional structure. When one project is over, its personnel and resources are diverted to some new project, as undertaking a large number of small projects, is a typical feature of a matrix organisation.

Question 21
Organization structure that shows a unique combination of strategy, structure and management process is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.free-form organization
  • B.virtual organization
  • C.network organization
  • D.horizontal organization
Correct Answer: network organization

Organization structure that shows a unique combination of strategy, structure and management process is known as Network Organization.

 

Types of organizational structures:

1. Line Organization: It is the simplest and oldest form of organization. It is generally used in the armed forces and thus also known as military organization. Other names of line organization are departmental organization, scalar organization and vertical organization. The organizational structure is based on authority and responsibility. The person at the top position of the organization has the highest authority and the authority reduces at each succession of the hierarchy. 

 

2. Line and Staff Organization: It is an extension of the line organization. This structure is based on F.W. Taylor’s “Foremanship Concept”. Here the line of authority remains unbroken, but at the same time, staff is also appointed to facilitate line persons. Staff means a team of experts. The staff is responsible for giving expert advice and other related assistance to line managers.

 

3. Functional Organization: It is based on the fact that there are many functions and these functions are performed to carry out business operations. Further, every function is performed by a specialist under a specific head. This type of structure is created by grouping and classifying the necessary activities to achieve organizational objectives. The classification is based on nature and importance of activities. Each group of activities is referred to as a function.

 

4. Divisional Organization: It is used organizations that operate in multiple geographical areas and/or diversifies into unrelated products. The whole organization is divided in autonomous units or divisions. Each unit is relatively self-contained and can operate independently. Each division has its own manufacturing and marketing facilities and is headed by a manager.

 

5. Committee Organization: Committee consists of a group of people and all the organizational decisions are taken by the committee. The distinguishing feature of a committee organization is that there is a committee for a particular functional department. For example, instead of a marketing manager, there is a marketing committee for marketing activities. 

 

6. Project Organization: It was developed after WWII to overcome the major weaknesses of functional organization such as violation of unity of command, delay in decision-making, lack of coordination and complexity. It may be temporary in nature, if the company wants to complete the projects at once. Each project is considered as a separate and semi-autonomous unit and all the necessary provisions are made for each project. A project manager is appointed to direct and coordinate various activities of the project and is responsible for its completion.

 

7. Matrix Organization: It is a hybrid grid structure made by combining key features of pure project structure and functional structure. It employs a multiple command system that includes multiple command structure, but also related support mechanism and an associated organizational culture and behaviour pattern. It includes a permanent functional structure along with temporary project groups. A project manager is appointed to coordinate and control activites of the project. The required personnel are drawn from their respective functional departments. 

 

8. Free-Form Organization: Free-form organization is a special type of team-based organization without organizational hierarchy and senior-subordinate positions that can successfully operate in a dynamic environment with a flexibility, speed and adaptability. It is unique kind of task force that is created to handle unusual problems.

 

9. Horizontal Organization: It is a customer-driven modern form of organization characterized by reduced hierarchy, direct information link with participants, team-based performance evaluation and reward, emphasis on multiple competencies, openness in dealing and end result process-based organization that enables the firms to facilitate speed in action, flexibility with situation and comfortable cooperation.

 

10. Network Organization: It is an improvement over horizontal design. It is based on horizontal coordination and collaboration beyond the boundaries of the organization. It is totally free from the classical, hierarchical and functional structure of organization. Internet technology, advanced telecommunication and continuous globalization have made it possible to form a network that can link people, organizations and systems of the whole world. This type of organization can be formed by subcontracting firms’ major functions to separate enterprises and coordinating their activities from small headquarter organizations. BPO firms widely follow this type of organizational design. Miles and Snow, the organization theorists, identified this design and called it a dynamic network that shows a unique combination of strategy, structure and management process.

 

11. Virtual Organization: It is also known as the digital or dotcom organization. It is closely related to network organization; it is an information-based network organization. Fred Luthans stated that “virtual organization is a temporary network of companies that come together quickly to exploit fast changing opportunities.” Thus, it may be referred to as the extended/revised form of the network design as it also represents information technology, partnering, strategic alliance and outsourcing arrangements. 

 

12. Entrepreneurial Organization: Small business firms (e.g- sole proprietary and partnership firms) in initial stages of inception usually follow entrepreneur type simple organization structure. It is a special type of line organization. It consists of an owner who works as the head or the manager for the employees. Employees support the manager to carry out relevant operations and perform multiple tasks.

Question 22
Which one among the following is the oldest form of organization? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Committee Organization
  • B.Line Organization
  • C.Project Organization
  • D.Functional Organization
Correct Answer: Line Organization

The oldest form of organization is Line Organization. Line organisation is the simplest and the oldest type of organisation. It is also known as scalar organisation or military type of organisation. In the words of J.M. Lundy, “It is characterized by direct lines of authority flowing from the top to the bottom of the organizational hierarchy and lines of responsibility flowing in an opposite but equally direct manner.”

 

An important characteristic of such type of organisation is superior-subordinate relationship. Superior delegates authority to another subordinate and so on, forming a line from the very top to the bottom of the organisation structure. The line of authority so established is referred as “line authority.” Under this type of organisation authority flows downwards, responsibility moves upwards in a straight line. Scalar principle and unity of command are strictly followed in line organisation.

 

This type of organisation resembles with the army administration or military type of organisation. As in case of military, commander-in-chief holds the top most position and has the entire control over the army of the country, which in turn is developed into main area commands under major-generals.

 

Each area has brigade under brigadier-generals, each brigade is fabricated into regiments under its colonels, each regiment into battalions under majors, each battalion into companies under captains, each company sub-divided under its lieutenants and so on drawn to corporal with his squad.

Question 23
Who among the following focussed on the soft side of an organization as a sequel to globalization comprising adhocracy, simple structure, the divisionalized form, the machine bureaucracy and the professional bureaucracy? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)
  • A.Bartlett and Ghoshal
  • B.Burns and Stalker
  • C.Henry Mintzberg
  • D.J. S. Black
Correct Answer: Henry Mintzberg

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Using the 3 basic dimensions — key part of the organization, prime coordinating mechanism, and type of decentralization — Mintzberg suggests that the strategy an organization adopts and the extent to which it practices that strategy result in 5 structural configurations: simple structure, machine bureaucracy, professional bureaucracy, divisionalized form, and adhocracy.

Question 24
Who described the mechanistic and organic or behavioural organization structures? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.Tom Burns and G. M. Stalker
  • B.Terry and Franklin
  • C.Robert H Miles
  • D.Kathryn M. Bartol and David C Martin
Correct Answer: Tom Burns and G. M. Stalker

Burns and Stalker claimed “a mechanistic management system is appropriate to stable conditions” whereas an “organismic form is appropriate to changing conditions, which give rise constantly to fresh problems and unforeseen requirements for action which cannot be broken down or distributed automatically arising from the functional roles defined with a hierarchic structure.”

 

The properties of both types of firms are described by Burns and Stalker below:

 

Mechanistic Systems:

  • the specialized differentiation of functional tasks into which the problems and tasks facing the concern are broken down
  • the abstract nature of each individual task, which is pursued with techniques and purposes more or less distinct from those of the concern as a whole; i.e., the functionaries tend to pursue the technical improvement of means, rather than the accomplishment of the ends of the concern
  • the reconciliation, for each level in the hierarchy, of these distinct performances by the immediate superiors, who are also, in turn, responsible for seeing that each is relevant in his own special part of the main task
  • The precise definition of rights and obligations and technical methods attached to each functional role
  • the translation of rights, and obligations, and methods into the responsibilities of a functional position
  • hierarchic structure of control, authority and communication
  • a reinforcement of hierarchic structure by the location of knowledge of actualities exclusively at the top of the hierarchy, where the final reconciliation of distinct tasks and assessment of relevant is made
  • a tendency for vertical interaction between members of the concern, i.e., between superior and subordinate
  • a tendency for operations and working behaviour to be governed by the instructions and decisions issued by superiors
  • insistence on loyalty to the concern and obedience to superiors as a condition of membership
  • a greater importance and prestige attaching to internal (local) than to general (cosmopolitan) knowledge, experience, and skill.

 

Organic Systems:

  • the contributive nature of special knowledge and experience to the common task of the concern
  • the realistic nature of the individual task, which is seen as set by the total situation of the concern
  • the adjustment and continual re-definition of individual tasks through interaction with others
  • the shedding of responsibility as a limited field of rights, obligations and methods. (Problems may not be posted upwards, downwards or sideways as being someone else’s responsibility)
  • the spread of commitment to the concern beyond any technical definition
  • a network structure of control, authority, and communication. The sanctions which apply to the individual’s conduct in his working role derive more from presumed community of interest with the rest of the working organization in the survival and growth of the firm, and less from a contractual relationship between himself and a non-personal corporation, represented for him by an immediate superior
  • omniscience no longer imputed to the head of the concern; knowledge about the technical or commercial nature of the here and now task may be located anywhere in the network; this location becoming the ad hoc center of control, authority and communication.
  • a lateral rather than a vertical direction of communication through the organization, communication between people of different rank, also, resembling consultation rather than command:
  • a content of communication which consists of information and advice rather than instructions and decisions
  • commitment to the concern’s tasks and to the ‘technological ethos’ of material progress and expansion is more highly valued than loyalty and obedience

importance and prestige attach to affiliations and expertise valid in the industrial and technical and commercial milieu external to the firm.

Question 25
“A horizontal set of divisional reporting relationship is superimposed on a hierarchical functional structure. This is known as grid organization or project management organization.” What type of structure it has? Choose the correct one from the alternatives given below: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)
  • A.Hybrid structure
  • B.Functional structure
  • C.Matrix structure
  • D.Divisional structure
Correct Answer: Matrix structure

The matrix structure is a blend of functional and divisional structures, creating a hybrid model where employees report to both functional managers and project or product managers. This setup is characterized by a horizontal set of divisional reporting relationships superimposed on a hierarchical functional structure.

 

In a matrix structure, employees belong to functional departments (like finance, marketing, or HR) while also being part of a project team or division that cuts across those functional lines. This duality allows individuals to work on specific projects or products while maintaining their functional roles within the organization.

 

Therefore, the correct answer to the question is (C) Matrix structure.

Question 26
Matrix organisation is the combination of: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.Functional organisation and Product organisation
  • B.Project and Line organisation
  • C.Project and Functional organisation
  • D.Line and Staff organization
Correct Answer: Project and Functional organisation

A Matrix Organisation is a hybrid structure that combines elements of both functional organisation and project organisation. In this structure:

Employees report to two supervisors:
A functional manager (who oversees specific technical expertise or departmental work).
A project manager (who manages the project as a whole, integrating inputs from different functions).

This dual authority helps leverage the benefits of functional specialization and flexibility in managing projects.

This structure is common in industries like IT, construction, and consulting, where projects are of high importance alongside functional expertise.

Question 27
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2022)Statement I:In a Matrix Organization, specialists from different functional departments work on projects that are led by a Project Manager.Statement II:One unique aspect of Matrix Organization is that it creates a unity of command managers coordinate and resolve conflicts.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I is correct: In a Matrix Organization, specialists from various functional departments collaborate on projects under the guidance or leadership of a Project Manager. This setup allows for a pooling of diverse talents and expertise from different areas of the organization to work on specific projects or initiatives.

 

Statement II is incorrect: The matrix structure, characterized by dual reporting lines and multiple bosses, can sometimes lead to conflicts arising from divided loyalties or conflicting directives. The complexity of reporting to both functional managers and project managers might create challenges in resolving conflicts or maintaining a clear chain of command. Thus, it doesn't inherently create a unity of command, rather it introduces complexities in reporting relationships.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate choice is (C) Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.

Question 28
Which of the following factors would not lead to narrow span of management? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2022)
  • A.Inadequate delegation of authority.
  • B.Fast changing environment.
  • C.Effective interaction between superior and subordinate.
  • D.Subordinate's unwillingness to assume responsibility.
Correct Answer: Effective interaction between superior and subordinate.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Effective interaction between superiors and subordinates is more likely to promote a narrow span of management. When there's a strong emphasis on close supervision, frequent communication, and hands-on involvement between managers and their subordinates, it often results in a narrower span of management.

 

Factors like inadequate delegation of authority (A), a fast-changing environment (B), and subordinate's unwillingness to assume responsibility (D) can contribute to a narrow span of management. These factors can limit a manager's ability to delegate tasks, adapt quickly to changes, and trust subordinates to take on responsibilities, thereby leading to a narrower span of management.

Question 29
Recentralisation is:(a)acomplete reversal of decentralisation.(b)acomplete centralisation of all activities.(c)adecentralisation of all activities.(d)apartial centralisation as the authority delegated is not completely withdrawn.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2022)
  • A.a and b Only
  • B.a, b and d Only
  • C.c Only
  • D.d Only
Correct Answer: d Only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Recentralization refers to the process of partially centralizing power and authority that was previously delegated to lower levels of government or other entities. This means that while some level of authority may be returned to the central governing body, it is not completely withdrawn from the entities that previously held it.

Question 30
An organisation structure defines how job, tasks are formally divided, grouped, and coordinated. Managers need to address six key elements when they design their organisation’s structure. (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)Match List-A with List-B given below:List-A: Refers to the six key elements encountered by managers in designing their organisation structure.List-B: Provides possible answer to address the key elements encountered in organisation designing.List-Aa. to what degree are activities subdivided into separate jobs?b. on what basis will jobs be grouped togetherc. to whom do individuals and groups report?d. how many individuals can a manager efficiently and effectively direct?e. where does decision making authority lie?f. to what degree will there be rules and regulations to direct employees and managersList-Bi. Span of Controlii. Centralization and Decentralisationiii. Departmentalizationiv. Work Specializationv. Chain of commandvi. Formalisation
  • A.a-iii, b-iv, c-v, d-ii, e-i, f-vi
  • B.a-iv, b-iii, c-v, d-i, e-ii, f-vi
  • C.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv, e-vi, f-v
  • D.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-vi, e-v, f-i
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-v, d-i, e-ii, f-vi

Let us match the elements encountered by managers in designing their organization's structure with their corresponding answers:

 

a. To what degree are activities subdivided into separate jobs? - iv. Work Specialization

b. On what basis will jobs be grouped together? - iii. Departmentalization

c. To whom do individuals and groups report? - v. Chain of command

d. How many individuals can a manager efficiently and effectively direct? - i. Span of Control

e. Where does decision-making authority lie? - ii. Centralization and Decentralization

f. To what degree will there be rules and regulations to direct employees and managers? - vi. Formalization

 

Therefore, the correct matching is (B) a-iv, b-iii, c-v, d-i, e-ii, f-vi

Question 31
Which of the following has specialists from different functional departments working on one or more projects that are led by a project manager? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)
  • A.Functional Organisation
  • B.Cross-Functional Team
  • C.Matrix Organisation
  • D.Product Organisation
Correct Answer: Matrix Organisation

The correct answer is (C) Matrix Organisation

 

In a Matrix Organisation, specialists from different functional departments work together on specific projects or tasks that are led by a project manager. This structure allows individuals to have dual reporting relationships – one based on their function and another based on the project they are currently involved in. This facilitates better coordination, collaboration, and utilization of expertise from various departments to accomplish project goals.

Question 32
If the number of subordinates is ‘n’, the total number of relationships, according to Graicunas formula, would be: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2015)
  • A.nn22+n-1
  • B.n2n2+n-1
  • C.2n2+n-1
  • D.2n22+n-1
Correct Answer: n2n2+n-1

V. A. Graicunas developed a formula for determining the no. of possible relationships between a manager and subordinates when the no. of subordinates is known. Graicunas’s Formula is as follows:

r = n ((2^n)/2+(n-1)), where r is number of relationships and n is number of subordinates.

Question 33
Which organisational structure is considered most complex? (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Functional structure
  • B.Divisional structure
  • C.Strategic Business Unit (SBU) structure
  • D.Matrix structure
Correct Answer: Matrix structure

The Matrix Structure is considered the most complex organizational structure among the options provided. Unlike the Functional, Divisional, or SBU structures, the Matrix Structure involves a combination of functional and project-based reporting relationships. In a matrix structure, employees belong to both functional departments and project teams, which can create complexities due to dual reporting lines, diverse priorities, and the need for strong coordination among various functions and projects. This complexity often arises from the multiple lines of authority and the necessity for effective communication and collaboration across different dimensions of the organization.

Question 34
Departmentation is (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)a. structuring work to accomplish organisational goalsb. visual display of organisation structurec. grouping of jobs on some basisd. arranging jobs in a hierarchy
  • A.a and b only
  • B.b and c only
  • C.a only
  • D.c only
Correct Answer: c only

The correct answer is (D) c only

 

Departmentation refers specifically to the grouping of jobs or activities within an organization based on certain criteria or basis. It involves categorizing tasks and jobs into units or departments to facilitate the management of related activities and resources.

Question 35
Which of the following is not a characteristic of ‘Spaghetti organization structure’ adopted by MNCs? (UGC NET HRM Jan 2017)
  • A.Paperless organisation
  • B.Smart office design
  • C.‘Meat Balls’ or knowledge centres
  • D.Formal communication between people
Correct Answer: Formal communication between people

In 1990 in Oticon, a large Danish manufacturer of hearing aids, a new style of management called "Spaghetti Organisation" was introduced with following principles:

  • No barriers to open communication in order to develop and support knowledge workers (no doors, no offices, instead of a permanent desk each employee has a mobile caddie cart, no papers since all mail is scanned into the computer and thus virtually accessible to all employees)
  • No job titles or job descriptions which eliminates categorization of employees and which maximizes development opportunities (ability to be a “category killer”)
  • Rewards/salary based on specific individual or team performance in order to encourage/develop initiative, cooperation and knowledge sharing
  • Each employee select their own mentor who conducts annual reviews and guidance sessions in order to support employee learning and development, and establish performance feedback
  • Each employee must organize themselves in teams to create and tackle whatever projects need doing and dissolve the team after the task is completed (employees are thus expected to gain support for a project idea or find a project team that needs the employees skills)

No line management or departments except for executive corporate management.

Question 36
Arrange the following steps of developing an organizational structure in sequence. (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. Enumerate and group the activities of the enterprise consistent with the determined objectives.b. Assign the grouped activities to personnel. Similar functions should be combined into one position.c. Clearly define the objectives to determine the type, stability and basic characteristics of the organization.d. Determine the span of supervision, the types of organization, the basis of departmentation and pattern of authority structure.e. Assess the capacities and abilities of human and other resources at the disposal of enterprise. Adapt the organization in sync with the reality.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, a, b, d, e
  • B.a, c, b, e, d
  • C.c, b, a, e, d
  • D.e, d, c, a, b
Correct Answer: c, a, b, d, e

The first step in developing an organizational structure is to clearly define the objectives, as this will determine the type, stability, and basic characteristics of the organization. Once the objectives are defined, the next step is to enumerate and group the activities of the enterprise consistent with the determined objectives. After grouping the activities, they should be assigned to personnel, with similar functions combined into one position. The next step is to determine the span of supervision, the types of organization, the basis of departmentation, and pattern of authority structure. Finally, the capacities and abilities of human and other resources should be assessed, and the organization should be adapted in sync with the reality to ensure that it can effectively achieve its objectives.

Question 37
Which one of the following factors is not a factor in case of wide span of Management? [UGC NET Management June 2022]
  • A.Fast changes in external and internal environment
  • B.Well-defined plans for repetitive operations
  • C.Effective interaction between superior and subordinate
  • D.Thorough training of subordinate
Correct Answer: Fast changes in external and internal environment

The factor that is not related to a wide span of management is (A) Fast changes in external and internal environment

 

A wide span of management is generally facilitated by well-defined plans for repetitive operations, effective interaction between superiors and subordinates, and thorough training of subordinates. However, fast changes in the external and internal environment might necessitate a more controlled and narrower span of management to ensure adaptability and agility in responding to these changes.

Question 38
Neo-classical organisation theory emphasises on which one of thefollowing ?(UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Flat structure of organisation
  • B.Tall structure of organisation
  • C.Coordination by hierarchy
  • D.Unity of command
Correct Answer: Flat structure of organisation

The Neo-classical organization theory emphasizes (A) Flat structure of organization

 

Neo-classical theories shifted focus from the rigid hierarchical structures to more flexible, flattened organizational structures, encouraging greater participation, open communication, and reduced layers of management. This approach aimed to enhance efficiency and adaptability within organizations.

Question 39
According to Graicuna’s formula of span of management, if a superior has three subordinates, what number of cross-relationships would be? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.three
  • B.six
  • C.nine
  • D.eighteen
Correct Answer: six

. A. Graicunas developed a formula for determining the no. of possible relationships between a manager and subordinates when the no. of subordinates is known. Graicunas’s Formulas are as follows:

Direct Single Relationships = n

Cross relationships = n(n-1)

Direct Group relationships = n (2n2-1)

Total relationships = n (2n2+n-1)

The number of Cross relationships = 3(3-1) = 6

Question 40
Match the following: (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)Organizational Structurea. Functional Structureb. Divisional Structurec. Matrix Structured. Strategic Business Unit (SBU)Advantage1. Clarity of project objectives2. Smooth delegation of authority and responsibility3. Simple and unexpensive4. Ease of fixing accountability
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2
  • C.a-3, b-4, c-2, d-1
  • D.a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2
Correct Answer: a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2

Let's match the given organizational structures with their corresponding advantages:

a. Functional Structure -> 3. Simple and inexpensive

b. Divisional Structure -> 4. Ease of fixing accountability

c. Matrix Structure -> 1. Clarity of project objectives

d. Strategic Business Unit (SBU) -> 2. Smooth delegation of authority and responsibility

 

a. Functional Structure: This type of structure organizes employees based on specialized functions or roles, creating departments for specific functions like marketing, finance, or operations. The advantage of this structure is that it's simple and cost-effective. It allows for focused expertise in each function without unnecessary duplication or complexity.

 

b. Divisional Structure: In a divisional structure, the organization is divided into semi-autonomous divisions based on product lines, geographic locations, or customer segments. The advantage here is the ease of fixing accountability. Each division operates like a separate entity, making it easier to attribute performance and results to specific divisions.

 

c. Matrix Structure: This structure combines elements of both functional and divisional structures, allowing employees from different departments to work together under a project manager. The advantage lies in the clarity of project objectives. It ensures a clear understanding of project goals and objectives due to the focused project-based teams.

 

d. Strategic Business Unit (SBU): SBUs are autonomous units within a larger organization, operating as separate businesses. The advantage here is the smooth delegation of authority and responsibility. Each SBU operates with a degree of autonomy, allowing for efficient decision-making and accountability within each unit.

Question 41
Which one of the following is NOT an advantage of organization structure by product in a manufacturing company? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Places attention and effort on product line.
  • B.Requires less persons with general managerial abilities.
  • C.Improves coordination of functional activities.
  • D.Permits growth and diversity of products.
Correct Answer: Requires less persons with general managerial abilities.

The correct answer is (B) Requires less persons with general managerial abilities.

 

Organizational structure by product in a manufacturing company generally requires managers with specialized knowledge about the specific product lines or segments. This structure often demands managers with expertise and understanding related to those particular products rather than needing fewer persons with general managerial abilities.

Question 42
Which one of the following is NOT an advantage of the line organization? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.It ensures excellent discipline.
  • B.It fixes responsibility for the performance of tasks.
  • C.It is suitable for big organizations.
  • D.It is not expensive.
Correct Answer: It is suitable for big organizations.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The line organization is a type of organizational structure where authority flows in a straight line from the top level of management to the bottom level. This type of organization is suitable for small organizations where there is a clear chain of command and decision-making is centralized.

 

However, in big organizations, the line organization may not be suitable because it can lead to bureaucracy, delays in decision-making, and lack of flexibility. Large organizations usually require more specialized departments and teams, and the line organization may not allow for the necessary cross-functional collaboration and coordination. Additionally, a large number of employees in a line organization can result in a longer chain of command, leading to slower communication and decision-making.

Question 43
The main advantage of functional organization is (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.Simplicity
  • B.Specialisation
  • C.Experience
  • D.Authority
Correct Answer: Specialisation

The main advantage of a functional organization is (B) Specialisation

 

In a functional organizational structure, employees are grouped based on their specialized skills and expertise. This arrangement allows individuals to focus on specific functions or tasks within their area of expertise, fostering specialization. This specialization often leads to increased efficiency and expertise in handling tasks within their functional area.

Question 44
Which one of the following is not an advantage of organization structure by territory? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Makes control easy for top management.
  • B.Places responsibility at a lower level.
  • C.Improves coordination in a region.
  • D.Takes advantage of economies of local operations.
Correct Answer: Makes control easy for top management.

The correct answer is (A) Makes control easy for top management.

 

Organizational structure by territory is advantageous in various aspects, but it doesn't necessarily make control easy for top management. In fact, this structure might distribute control across different regions or territories, potentially making it more challenging for top management to maintain direct oversight and control over every operational aspect in each territory.

Question 45
Another name for MATRIX organisation is (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Flexible organisation
  • B.Geographic organisation
  • C.Project organisation
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Project organisation

A Matrix Organization, also known as a Project Organization, is a unique structural setup within a company where employees are grouped based on both their functional expertise and their assignment to specific projects. In this structure, specialists from different departments collaborate and work under a project manager to achieve the goals of particular projects.

 

This approach allows for a dynamic work environment where individuals from various departments bring their expertise to bear on a project's needs. Rather than solely following the traditional hierarchical structure, employees work across functional boundaries, promoting greater communication, diverse skill utilization, and collaboration.

 

The term "matrix" signifies a grid-like or intersecting structure where employees report to both a functional manager (representing their departmental expertise) and a project manager (for the project they're currently engaged in). It provides flexibility and agility by pooling resources across the organization to tackle specific project challenges.

Question 46
The control based on norms, shared values, expected behaviour, and other cultural variables in an organisation is known as: (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)
  • A.Bureaucratic Control
  • B.System Control
  • C.Tailoring Control
  • D.Clan Control
Correct Answer: Clan Control

Clan Control is the appropriate answer. It embodies a more cultural and values-driven approach to organizational control. Unlike bureaucratic control, which relies heavily on rules and regulations, Clan Control emphasizes shared values, cultural norms, and the cultivation of informal relationships to steer and regulate employee behavior within the organization. It operates on a foundation of trust and often involves employees in setting standards and designing control systems, fostering a more participatory environment.

Quiz Attempt #118948

Total Questions: 46
Question 1
Which of the following statements are not true relating to grapevine?(UGC NET HRM Jun 2024)A. Information usually travels relativelymore slowthrough grapevine.B. Grapevines are found in everyorganisation.C. The grapevine is a more spontaneous form of communication.D. The number of people who serve as actual links in the grapevine are generally large.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.C and D only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and D only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: A and D only

To determine which statements are not true regarding the grapevine, let's analyze each statement:

 

A. Information usually travels relatively more slowly through grapevine.

Not True: Grapevine communication is often fast, sometimes even quicker than formal communication channels.

 

B. Grapevines are found in every organization.

True: Informal communication networks, or grapevines, exist in virtually every organization as employees share information informally.

 

C. The grapevine is a more spontaneous form of communication.

True: The grapevine is characterized by spontaneous, informal communication that occurs among employees.

 

D. The number of people who serve as actual links in the grapevine are generally large.

Not True: Usually, grapevine communication often involves a smaller, select group of individuals who serve as links rather than a large number.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C) A and D only.

Question 2
Sequentially arrange the following communication channels from low to high: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2024)(A) Letters(B) Telephone conversations(C) Electronic mail(D) Face-to-face conversations(E) Voice mailChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(A), (B), (C), (E), (D)
  • B.(C), (E), (A), (B), (D)
  • C.(A), (C), (E), (B), (D)
  • D.(A), (B), (D), (C), (E)
Correct Answer: (A), (C), (E), (B), (D)

The correct answer is (C) (A), (C), (E), (B), (D).

 

The communication channels can be ranked from low to high based on their ability to convey richness and immediacy of communication. The more rich a communication channel is, the more it can convey emotions, tone, and other non-verbal cues, and the more immediate the response.

 

(A) Letters:
Letters are the least rich communication channel as they are written and do not allow for immediate feedback or non-verbal cues. They are often formal and asynchronous.

 

(C) Electronic mail (Email):
Email is more immediate than letters and allows for quicker responses, but it still lacks non-verbal cues and can be more formal or less personal than other communication methods.

 

(E) Voice mail:
Voice mail allows for the tone and emotion of speech to be conveyed but lacks the immediacy of a real-time conversation. It is more personal than written communication but still lacks the real-time interaction.

 

(B) Telephone conversations:
Telephone conversations are more interactive and allow for real-time communication, which makes them richer than emails and voice mails. However, they still lack non-verbal cues like facial expressions or body language.

 

(D) Face-to-face conversations:
Face-to-face conversations are the richest form of communication, as they allow for immediate feedback, verbal and non-verbal cues (such as body language and facial expressions), and a high level of personal interaction.

Question 3
Gangplank theory of communication advanced by Henry Fayol is an example of: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2009)
  • A.Downward Communication
  • B.Lateral Communication
  • C.Upward Communication
  • D.Network Communication
Correct Answer: Lateral Communication

The Gangplank theory introduced by Henri Fayol aimed to facilitate communication horizontally, between individuals or departments at the same hierarchical level. This horizontal communication is often termed "Lateral Communication" in organizational contexts.

 

Fayol proposed this mechanism to bridge communication gaps and enable direct interaction among peers or employees at the same level within the organization. It allowed for quicker exchanges of information, collaboration, and problem-solving without solely relying on the vertical chain of command.

 

Hence, the correct answer is (B) Lateral Communication because the Gangplank theory focused on enhancing communication horizontally or laterally across the organization.

Question 4
Which of the following statements about communication is/are either true or false? (UGC NET HRM Jul 2016)a. Gang plank theory is a type of vertical communication.b. Encoded messages are not always decoded effectively because of different fields of organism.c. ‘Filtering’ is not an intervention which vitiates communication.d. ‘Grapevine’ moves faster than formal communication.
  • A.aand c are true; b and d are false.
  • B.aand d are true; b and c are false.
  • C.band d are true; a and c are false.
  • D.a, b and c are true; and d is false.
Correct Answer: band d are true; a and c are false.

Let's break down each statement:

 

a. Gangplank theory is a type of vertical communication. (False)

The Gangplank theory, introduced by Henri Fayol, is not a form of vertical communication. Instead, it facilitates horizontal or lateral communication. It enables direct communication between individuals at the same hierarchical level in different departments, aiming to bridge communication gaps and enhance efficiency, especially in emergencies.

 

b. Encoded messages are not always decoded effectively because of different fields of organism. (True)

Encoded messages might not always be decoded effectively due to various barriers or differences between the sender and receiver. Factors such as personal biases, emotions, values, and differing frames of reference (fields of organism) can hinder effective decoding of messages. These differences can lead to misunderstandings or misinterpretations.

 

c. ‘Filtering’ is not an intervention which vitiates communication. (False)

Filtering is a significant factor that can hinder effective communication. It involves the deliberate manipulation or distortion of information by the sender to influence the receiver's perception. It often leads to the withholding of certain details or altering information, impacting the accuracy and transparency of communication.

 

d. ‘Grapevine’ moves faster than formal communication. (True)

The grapevine refers to informal communication channels within an organization, primarily based on rumors and gossip. It operates independently of formal communication channels, and due to its informal nature, information spreads quickly through the grapevine. It often moves faster than formal communication channels, as there are fewer restrictions or controls over its dissemination.

 

Therefore, the correct statements are b and d are true; a and c are false (C) based on the explanations provided for each statement.

Question 5
Assertion “A”:Under stressful situations, a person is unable to listen to and understand the message correctly.Reasoning “R”:During stressful situations, the psychological frame of mind changes and the message gets distorted due to the beliefs, experiences, goals and values held by the receiver of the message.(UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.“A” and “R” both are correct and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.
  • B.“A” and “R” both are correct but “R” is not the correct explanation of “A”.
  • C.“A” is correct whereas “R” is incorrect.
  • D.“R” is correct whereas “A” is incorrect.
Correct Answer: “A” and “R” both are correct and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.

The assertion "A" states that under stressful situations, a person is unable to listen to and understand the message correctly. This assertion is correct.

 

The reasoning "R" explains that during stressful situations, the psychological frame of mind changes, and the message gets distorted due to the beliefs, experiences, goals, and values held by the receiver of the message. This reasoning provides a valid explanation for why a stressed individual might struggle to receive and interpret a message accurately.

 

Hence, both Assertion "A" and Reasoning "R" are correct, and Reasoning "R" does offer a suitable explanation for Assertion "A." Therefore, the correct answer is (A) "A" and "R" both are correct and "R" is the correct explanation of "A."

Question 6
Which of the following is a process of communication? (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)
  • A.Downward
  • B.Upward
  • C.Lateral
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

The process of communication in an organization encompasses different directions and forms. Here's an explanation for each type:

 

1. Downward Communication: This flow involves information passing from higher levels of the organizational hierarchy to lower levels. It includes directives, instructions, policies, goals, and other information disseminated from superiors to subordinates.

 

2. Upward Communication: This refers to the flow of information from lower levels of the organization to higher levels. It involves feedback, suggestions, grievances, reports, or ideas from subordinates to their superiors. It's crucial for ensuring that the concerns and insights from the lower ranks reach the decision-makers.

 

3. Lateral or Horizontal Communication: This type of communication occurs between individuals or units at the same hierarchical level or across different departments within the organization. It's essential for coordination, cooperation, problem-solving, and sharing information among peers.

 

All three—downward, upward, and lateral communication—are integral components of the communication process within an organization, serving various purposes and facilitating the smooth functioning of the organizational structure and its operations. Therefore, the correct answer is indeed (D) All the above as they collectively represent different processes and directions of communication within an organization.

Question 7
Which of the following is not a path in grapevine chain? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)
  • A.Non-profitability
  • B.Single strand
  • C.Gossip
  • D.Cluster Chair
Correct Answer: Non-profitability

Grapevine communication has been classified into four types:

 

1. Single Strand Chain: In this type of grapevine communication the information passes through a number of persons like a chain. A tells something to B, who tells it to C, who tells it to D and so on.

It is generally a long chain. The longer the chain the greater is the possibility of distortion of the information.

 

2. Gossip Chain: In Gossip Chain one person actively conveys information to other persons around him. A circle or wheel-like figure is formed in this communication. Here, in this picture. A is at the centre and transmits messages to ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’, ‘E’, ‘F, ‘G’, and ‘H’ around him/her. Gossip Chain is generally used when information to be communicated is non-job oriented in nature.

 

3. Probability Chain: It is a random process in which information may move from one person to any other person or persons according to law of probability. Naturally, in this type of communication, some people of the organisation will be informed and some others will remain outside the arena of the communication.

Here, in the illustration, E, F, G and K are outside the communication chain. This chain is used when information is interesting but less important.

 

4. Cluster Chain: Cluster chain is mostly used and the dominant pattern of grapevine communication. In this type one person tells something to some selected trust worthy persons. Some of these persons may inform a few selected other individuals.

Here in the picture, A tells some selected and trustworthy persons, B, C and D. C again relays it to his selected persons, G, H and I. D tells J, a person of his choice. E and F remain outside the cluster.

 

The correct answer is option A.

Question 8
When a sender manipulates information so that it will be seen more favourably by the receiver in communication, it is called: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)
  • A.Selective Perception
  • B.Linguistic Trap
  • C.Filtering
  • D.Emotional Appeal
Correct Answer: Filtering

Communicating can be more of a challenge than you think, when you realize the many things that can stand in the way of effective communication. These include filtering, selective perception, information overload, emotional disconnects, lack of source familiarity or credibility, workplace gossip, semantics, gender differences, differences in meaning between Sender and Receiver, and biased language.

 

Filtering is the distortion or withholding of information to manage a person’s reactions. Some examples of filtering include a manager who keeps her division’s poor sales figures from her boss, the vice president, fearing that the bad news will make him angry. A gatekeeper who doesn’t pass along a complete Message is also filtering. 

 

Selective perception refers to filtering what we see and hear to suit our own needs. This process is often unconscious. Small things can command our attention when we’re visiting a new place—a new city or a new company. Over time, however, we begin to make assumptions about the way things are on the basis of our past experience. Often, much of this process is unconscious. 

 

Information overload can be defined as “occurring when the information processing demands on an individual’s time to perform interactions and internal calculations exceed the supply or capacity of time available for such processing.” Messages reach us in countless ways every day. Some are societal—advertisements that we may hear or see in the course of our day. Others are professional—e-mails, and memos, voice mails, and conversations from our colleagues. Others are personal—messages and conversations from our loved ones and friends. Add these together and it’s easy to see how we may be receiving more information than we can take in. This state of imbalance is known as information overload.

 

Emotional disconnects happen when the Sender or the Receiver is upset, whether about the subject at hand or about some unrelated incident that may have happened earlier. An effective communication requires a Sender and a Receiver who are open to speaking and listening to one another, despite possible differences in opinion or personality. One or both parties may have to put their emotions aside to achieve the goal of communicating clearly. A Receiver who is emotionally upset tends to ignore or distort what the Sender is saying. A Sender who is emotionally upset may be unable to present ideas or feelings effectively.

Question 9
Grapevine is a type of: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Formal Communication
  • B.Written Communication
  • C.Lateral Communication
  • D.Informal Communication
Correct Answer: Informal Communication

Grapevine communication is the informal communication network within an organization. The grapevine is used to spread information bypassing the formal communication structure. Just like the grapevine plant: it spreads in random ways and it goes where it can. The grapevine is formed by individuals and groups in an organization. The people in the groups have something in common that links them together.

Question 10
Which of the following is not a semantic barrier of communication? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2012)
  • A.Faulty translation
  • B.Ambiguous words
  • C.Specialist’s language
  • D.Inattention
Correct Answer: Inattention

Inattention is the Personal barrier of communication.

 

Semantic Barriers: There is always a possibility of misunderstanding the feelings of the sender of the message or getting a wrong meaning of it. The words, signs, and figures used in the communication are explained by the receiver in the light of his experience which creates doubtful situations. The chief language-related barriers are as under: (i) Badly Expressed Message (ii) Symbols or Words with Different Meanings (iii) Faulty Translation (iv) Unclarified Assumptions (v) Technical Jargon (vi) Body Language and Gesture Decoding.

Question 11
Which of the following is correct about ‘Grapevine’? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2012)
  • A.It tends to exist when members of formal group know one another well.
  • B.It is the result of social forces at work place.
  • C.It is more common in times of high organisational excitement.
  • D.All the above.
Correct Answer: All the above.

Grapevine communication is the informal communication network within an organization. The grapevine is used to spread information bypassing the formal communication structure. Just like the grapevine plant: it spreads in random ways and it goes where it can. The grapevine is formed by individuals and groups in an organization. The people in the groups have something in common that links them together.

Question 12
Premature evaluation of message takes place due to (UGC NET HRM Dec 2010)
  • A.Semantic Barriers
  • B.Psychological Barriers
  • C.Organizational Barriers
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Psychological Barriers

Some people have the tendency to form a judgement before listening to the entire message. This is known as premature evaluation. Half-listening is like racing your engine with the gears in neutral. You use gasoline but you get nowhere. Premature evaluation distorts understanding and acts as a barrier to effective communication. This is Psychological or Emotional Barriers. 

 

Semantic barriers refer to the obstacles caused in communication due to problems with the interpretation of word meanings.

Question 13
Efficacy of written communication depends upon:(I) Lengthy presentation(II) Editing after writing(III) Brevity in sentences(IV) Use of strong words(V) Effective use of wordsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options below:[UGC NET Management June 2022]
  • A.II, III, V only
  • B.IV and V only
  • C.II, III, IV only
  • D.I, III, IV, V only
Correct Answer: II, III, V only

The efficacy of written communication indeed depends on several factors that enhance clarity, precision, and impact. Among the options provided:

 

Editing after writing (II): This involves revising, refining, and improving the content after the initial draft, ensuring accuracy and coherence. It helps eliminate errors and enhances the quality of the written piece.

 

Brevity in sentences (III): Writing succinctly and avoiding unnecessary lengthiness helps maintain reader engagement and clarity of message delivery.

 

Effective use of words (V): Selecting appropriate, impactful, and relevant words contributes significantly to the overall effectiveness of written communication.

 

Therefore, among the options presented, (A) II, III, V only accurately identifies factors crucial for ensuring the efficacy of written communication.

Question 14
Which one of the following is not an example of semantic barrier?(UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.Poorly chosen words and phrases
  • B.Faulty translation
  • C.Use of symbols that have various meanings
  • D.Guarding against certain type of information
Correct Answer: Guarding against certain type of information

Among the options provided, (D) Guarding against certain type of information does not align with the concept of a semantic barrier in communication.

 

Semantic barriers involve issues related to the understanding and interpretation of words, phrases, symbols, or language, leading to miscommunication or lack of clarity. Let's examine the other options:

 

Poorly chosen words and phrases (A): This can cause confusion or misunderstanding due to the ambiguity or inappropriateness of the language used, which aligns with semantic barriers.

 

Faulty translation (B): Translating information inaccurately from one language to another can result in misinterpretation and is an example of a semantic barrier.

 

Use of symbols that have various meanings (C): When symbols carry multiple interpretations or meanings, it can lead to confusion or misunderstanding, also fitting within the concept of semantic barriers.

Question 15
Which is NOT a centralized communication network system?
  • A.Wheel Network
  • B.Y-shaped Network
  • C.Circle Network
  • D.Chain Network
Correct Answer: Circle Network

Circle Network is not a centralized communication network system. The circle network and the all-channel network are more decentralized in that there is freer communication among the various members. In the circle network, each member can communicate with the individual on either side. The all-channel network is the most decentralized of the networks; each member can communicate with any other member.

 

Five types of Communication Network are as follows:

 

a. Y Network - In the Y network, for example, members A and B can send information to C, but they can receive information from no one. C and D can exchange information; E can receive information from D but cannot send any information. For example, two assistant principals, (A and B) report to the principal (C). The principal, in turn, reports to the assistant superintendent (D), who reports to the superintendent (E).

 

b. Wheel Network: Here all subordinates receive commands from one superior. This is highly centralized type of communication network where each subordinate receives commands or instructions from a single authority or superior ‘A’ and wants the immediate feedback.

 

c. Chain Network: Similar to Y network, chain network also follows a formal chain of command where information flows vertically upwards or downwards. A superior and subordinate communicate with each other through vertical chain of command, both upwards and downwards. Information distortion is not likely to take place but communication system becomes time consuming.

 

d. Circle Network: The circle network, a three-level hierarchy, is very different from the wheel, chain, and Y networks. It is symbolic of horizontal and decentralized communication. The circle gives every member equal communication opportunities. Each member can communicate with persons to their right and left. Members have identical restrictions, but the circle is a less restricted condition than the wheel, chain, or Y networks. In the circle network, everyone becomes a decision maker.

 

e. Star Network/ All channel Network: Under star communication network all members of the group communicate with each other and exchange information. This network is a must for group communication or where teamwork is involved. This network channel of communication is open to all members of the group. The members communicate with each other without hesitation.

Question 16
Diffusion of routine information takes place through:(UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Downward Communication
  • B.Upward Communication
  • C.Horizontal Communication
  • D.External Communication
Correct Answer: Downward Communication

The diffusion of routine information within an organization primarily occurs through Downward Communication. This flow involves the transmission of routine instructions, notices, circulars, memos, letters, and similar official information from higher-level authorities or management to subordinates or employees at lower levels of the organizational hierarchy.

 

Downward communication, as explained in the context provided, serves as a primary channel for routine information dissemination within an organization. It aligns with the formal chain of command, where superiors convey necessary instructions, policies, guidelines, and directives to their subordinates to ensure clarity in tasks and operations.
