Other forms of communication, such as upward communication (from lower levels to higher levels), horizontal communication (between individuals at the same hierarchical level), and external communication (with entities outside the organization) serve different purposes and involve different types of information exchange. However, for routine information dissemination within the organization's internal structure, downward communication is the key process involved.

Question 17
Out of the following, identify the four major functions which communication serves within a group or organization: (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)(a) Control(b) Co-ordination(c) Emotional expression(d) Information(e) Motivation(f) Organization
  • A.(a), (b), (d) and (f)
  • B.(b), (d), (e) and (f)
  • C.(a), (b), (d) and (e)
  • D.(a), (c), (d) and (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (c), (d) and (e)

Communication serves four major functions within a group or organization: control, motivation, emotional expression, and information. 

 

1. Communication acts to control member behaviour in several ways. Organizations have authority hierarchies and formal guidelines that employees are required to follow. When employees, for instance, are required to first communicate any job related grievance to their immediate boss, to follow their job description, or to comply with company policies, communication is performing a control function. 

 

2. Communication fosters motivation by clarifying to employees what is to be done, how well they are doing, and what can be done to improve performance if it's subpart. 

 

3. For many employees, their work group is a primary source for social interaction. The communication that takes place within the group is a fundamental mechanism by which members show their frustrations and feelings of satisfaction. Communication, therefore, provides a release for the emotional expression of feelings and for fulfilment of social needs.

 

4. The final function that communication performs relates to its role in facilitating decision making. It provides the information that individuals and groups need to make decisions by transmitting the data to identify and evaluate alternative choices.

Question 18
In _________ grapevine, a person transmits the information to a few selected people and some of them pass it on to select others. (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Cluster
  • B.Gossip
  • C.Probability
  • D.‘Single-strand chain’
Correct Answer: Cluster

Grapevine communication has been classified into four types:

 

1. Single Strand Chain: In this type of grapevine communication the information passes through a number of persons like a chain. A tells something to B, who tells it to C, who tells it to D and so on.

It is generally a long chain. The longer the chain the greater is the possibility of distortion of the information.

 

2. Gossip Chain: In Gossip Chain one person actively conveys information to other persons around him. A circle or wheel-like figure is formed in this communication. Here, in this picture. A is at the centre and transmits messages to ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’, ‘E’, ‘F, ‘G’, and ‘H’ around him/her. Gossip Chain is generally used when information to be communicated is non-job oriented in nature.

 

3. Probability Chain: It is a random process in which information may move from one person to any other person or persons according to law of probability. Naturally, in this type of communication, some people of the organisation will be informed and some others will remain outside the arena of the communication.

Here, in the illustration, E, F, G and K are outside the communication chain. This chain is used when information is interesting but less important.

 

4. Cluster Chain: Cluster chain is mostly used and the dominant pattern of grapevine communication. In this type one person tells something to some selected trust worthy persons. Some of these persons may inform a few selected other individuals.

Here in the picture, A tells some selected and trustworthy persons, B, C and D. C again relays it to his selected persons, G, H and I. D tells J, a person of his choice. E and F remain outside the cluster.

Question 19
The problem arising from expressions in communication are called.(UGC NET Management Jun 2020)
  • A.Spatial barriers
  • B.Semantic barriers
  • C.Wrong assumptions
  • D.Selected perception
Correct Answer: Semantic barriers

Semantic barriers are called the problems that arise from expressions in communication.

 

Semantics is the systematic study of “meaning”. That is why the problems arising from expression or transmission of meaning in communication are called semantic problems. The meaning is in the mind of the sender and in that of the receiver. But it is not always necessary for the meaning in the mind of the sender to be the same as in the mind of receiver. That leads to semantic problems. It can be ensured only if we aim at clarity, simplicity and brevity so that the receiver gets the intended meaning.

 

Spatial barriers or physical barriers: Space can act as barrier in a cross cultural or trans-national oral communication situation. Over-crowding in elevators, jostling in office corridors and elbowing in public transport systems are all external factors that do affect communication as barriers.

 

Wrong assumptions: Wrong assumptions are generally made because the sender or the receiver does not have adequate knowledge about the other’s background or entertains certain false concepts, which are fixed in his/her mind.

 

Varied or selected perceptions: This is when different individuals hold different viewpoints about the same situation.

Question 20
Psychological barriers in communication take place due to following reasons:(UGC NET Management Dec 2019)(a) Premature evaluation, lack of attention(b) Organizational facilities, status relationships(c) Poor retention, lack of reliance(d) Hierarchy, Organization policiesChoose the correct option:
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(a) and (c)
  • C.(b) and (c)
  • D.(b) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a) and (c)

Keith Devis has classified the communication barriers into three types: Personal, Physical, and Semantic.

 

1. Personal Barriers: Personal barriers, sometimes can also be termed as psychological barriers are communication interferences that arise from human emotions, values and poor listening. For instance, the receiver might not like the sender and therefore, interacts on the basis of the attitude of the sender.

(i) Premature Evaluation: Sometimes the receiver of information tries to dig out meaning without much thinking at the time of receiving or even before receiving information, which can be wrong. This type of evaluation is a hindrance in the exchange of information and the enthusiasm of the sender gets dampened.

(ii) Lack of Attention: When the receiver is preoccupied with some important work he/she does not listen to the message attentively. 

(iii) Loss by Transmission and Poor Retention: When a message is received by a person after it has passed through many people, generally it loses some of its truth. This is called loss by transmission. (iv) Distrust: For successful communication the transmitter and the receiver must trust each other. If there is a lack of trust between them, the receiver will always derive an opposite meaning from the message. Because of this, communication will become meaningless.

 

2. Physical Barriers: Physical barriers are communication interferences that occur in the environment in which the communication takes place. For instance, the voice of the sender might not be completely audible on the telephone.

 

3. Semantic Barriers: Semantic barriers arise from limitations in the symbols with which we communicate such as language which the receiver might not know or comprehend. Some examples are:

(i) Badly Expressed Message

(ii) Symbols or Words with Different Meanings

(iii) Faulty Translation

(iv) Unclarified Assumptions

(v) Technical Jargon

(vi) Body Language and Gesture Decoding

Question 21
Which among the following is also known as ‘Cross Contact’ communication?(UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Intra-scalar communication
  • B.Inter-scalar communication
  • C.Extra-organization communication
  • D.Concealed communication
Correct Answer: Intra-scalar communication

The term 'Cross Contact' communication in the context provided is known as Intra-scalar communication or Horizontal Communication.

 

Intra-scalar communication, also referred to as horizontal communication, occurs within the same hierarchical level or scalar level in an organization. It involves communication between individuals, teams, or departments at the same level in the organizational structure. This type of communication facilitates cooperation, coordination, and exchange of information between peers working under the same authority or at the same level of the organizational hierarchy.

 

This form of communication, as described, is essential for interdepartmental collaboration, problem-solving, sharing of information, and overall efficiency within an organization. It enables lateral or sideward information flow, allowing individuals at the same hierarchical level to communicate directly, bypassing the strict vertical chain of command.

 

Therefore, in the given options, (A) Intra-scalar communication is correctly identified as 'Cross Contact' communication or horizontal communication within the same scalar level in the organization.

Question 22
The study of gestures and body postures for their impact on communication is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Kinesics
  • B.Proximics
  • C.Semantics
  • D.Informal channels
Correct Answer: Kinesics

The study of gestures and body postures for their impact on communication is termed "Kinesics".

 

Kinesics specifically focuses on non-verbal communication related to body language, facial expressions, gestures, and postures, analyzing how these non-verbal cues convey messages and affect communication between individuals.

Question 23
The informal group’s communication system is called: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.Group Dynamics
  • B.Grapevine
  • C.Exchange
  • D.Interaction
Correct Answer: Grapevine

According to Bovee and others, “Grapevine is an informal interpersonal channel of information not officially sanctioned by the organization”. So, grapevine is an informal, unofficial and personal communication channel or system that takes place within the organization as a result of rumour and gossip. It is a complex web of oral information flow linking all the members of the organization.

Question 24
Given below are some of the barriers of communication:(a) Perceptions(b) Interpersonal sensitivity(c) Differing frames of reference(d) Information overloadFrom among the above identify the barriers, which are considered as sender-related barriers? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.(b) and (c)
  • B.(a) and (b)
  • C.(b) and (d)
  • D.(c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (b) and (c)

There are several barriers that affect the flow of communication in an organization. These barriers interrupt the flow of communication from the sender to the receiver, thus making communication ineffective. It is essential for management to overcome these barriers. The main barriers of communication are classified into three: 

 

Sender Related Barriers:  The sender is responsible for encoding ideas, thoughts and feeling, when this is not appropriately discharged; communication is bound to be ineffective. 

a. Communication Goals: - There must be a goal or objective in any kind of communication, lack of goal or objective can lead to incoherent (confused) messages. 

b. Communication Skills: - This refers to the clarity, word usage, correct spelling or pronunciation, body language and delivery of message, absence of these make it difficult to understand the message clearly. 

c. Interpersonal Sensitivity (segmentation): - The sender may convey the message correctly, but the receiver fails to get intended results, this may be either the message is not segmented to the receiver or it has not motivated the receiver to respond. 

d. Differing Frames of Reference: - The sender and receiver must use the common mode / field /way of expression which both are conversant with i.e. the sender and the receiver should have similar means of communication. 

e. Non-Verbal Signals: - Tone, voice modulation, facial expression and body language can help or hinder communication. e.g. quarrel at home may make boss behave indifferently.

f. Fear: - A person under the influence of fear is likely to lose balance and his message will be affected adversely, though he may be prepared well and good at communicating. 

g. Sender Credibility: - The amount of faith the receiver places on the message depends on the evaluation of the sender towards reliability or trustworthiness of the sender.

 

Situation Related Barriers: Situation also plays a major role in distortion of the communication, Though the sender is receiver have done their part fairly. The communication may become ineffective for some of the following reasons: 

a. Jargon: - means words or talks which is familiar only to a group, when these words are used out of the group it becomes a barrier e.g., legal terms., medical terms. etc. 

b. Information Overload: - if you receive a message with too much information or lots of information is termed as information overload which can also be a big hindrance in effective communication. 

c. Time Pressure: - may prevent the sender to provide adequate required information to the receiver. 

d. Culture Climate: - if it prevails in the atmosphere of trust and confidence, it is likely to provide a positive response or vice versa. 

e. Noise: - refers to the interference or distraction that is in the environment in which the communication is taking place. 

f. Emotions: - communication if engrossed in emotions for some reason; in such cases, we tend to have trouble listening to others or understanding the message conveyed. A few of the emotional interferences include hostility, anger, resentfulness etc. 

g. Stress: - at the time of stress, our psychological frame of mind depends on our beliefs, experiences, goals and values. Thus, we fail to realize the essence of communication. 

h. Complexity in Organizational Structure: greater the hierarchy in an organization (i.e., more the number of managerial levels), more is the chances of communication getting destroyed. Only the people at the top level can see the overall picture while the people at low level just have knowledge about their own area and a little knowledge about other areas.

 

Receiver Related Barriers: The receiver is responsible for decoding ideas, thoughts and feelings, when this is not appropriately received; communication is bound to be ineffective. The communication cycle may break down at the receiving end for some of these following reasons: 

a. Lack of Interest: - If a message reaches a reader who is not interested in the message, the reader may read the message hurriedly or listen to the message carelessly. Miscommunication may result in both cases. 

b. Lack of Knowledge: - If a receiver is unable to understand a message filled with technical information, communication will break down. 

c. Lack of Communication Skills: - Those who have weak reading and listening skills make ineffective receivers. 

d. Physical Distractions: - If a receiver of a communication works in an area with bright lights, glare on computer screens, loud noises, excessively hot or cold workspaces, or physical ailments, that receiver will probably experience communication breakdowns on a regular basis. 

e. Selective or Poor listening: - This refers to the receiver’s tendency to hear only to what, when, whom, where he is interested, and wants to disagree other information i.e., the receiver may not be a projective and active listener. 

f. Evaluating the Source: the receiver has the tendency to evaluate the sender not the message, if the receiver doesn’t like the person, he may not like what he is saying, thou it may be good and correct. 

g. Perceptions: 

(i) Stereotyping: - perceiving a communication or message based on some salient features of the sender e.g., age, region, religion, gender, etc. 

(ii) Halo effect: - refers to the tendency of the receiver, perceiving the sender in terms of good and bad, i.e., showing interest and responding to the sender whom the receiver likes and vice versa. 

h. Lack of Responsive Feedback: - Non-response or inappropriate responses discourages the sender of the message, which hurts the ego and feelings of the sender.

Question 25
Arrange the following elements of the process of interpersonal communication in sequential order:(a) the message(b) the channel(c) feedback(d) the sender(e) the receiver(f) the encoding(g) the decodingChoose your answer from the following options: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.(d), (f), (a), (b), (g), (e) and (c)
  • B.(a), (d), (e), (g), (b), (c) and (f)
  • C.(a), (b), (d), (f), (e), (c) and (g)
  • D.(b), (a), (c), (d), (f), (g) and (e)
Correct Answer: (d), (f), (a), (b), (g), (e) and (c)

The sequential order of the elements in the process of interpersonal communication is as follows:

 

1. The Sender (d): Initiates the communication process by generating a message to convey.

2. The Encoding (f): Involves converting the message into a suitable form for transmission.

3. The Message (a): The actual information or content that the sender intends to communicate.

4. The Channel (b): The medium through which the message is transmitted to the receiver.

5. The Decoding (g): The process where the receiver interprets and understands the encoded message.

6. The Receiver (e): Receives the message transmitted through the channel.

7. The Feedback (c): The response or reaction provided by the receiver back to the sender.

 

The correct sequential order of these elements in the process of interpersonal communication is (A) (d), (f), (a), (b), (g), (e), and (c).

Question 26
The term ‘grapevine’ is associated with which one of the following communication networks of an organization? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)
  • A.Formal communication
  • B.Horizontal communication
  • C.Informal communication
  • D.Vertical communication
Correct Answer: Informal communication

The term 'grapevine' is specifically linked to informal communication within an organization. It represents an unofficial, unofficially recognized, and informal network where information, rumors, or gossip circulate among employees or individuals outside the formal channels of communication.

 

This grapevine communication network operates independently of the formal hierarchical structure and can spread information rapidly, often transmitting news, rumors, or informal discussions faster than the formal channels.

 

Hence, the correct association of the term 'grapevine' is with (C) Informal communication within an organization.

Question 27
Which one of the following is not a barrier to communication? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)
  • A.feedback
  • B.ambiguity
  • C.lack of trust
  • D.distortions in communication
Correct Answer: feedback

The statement "feedback" is not typically considered a barrier to communication; instead, it's an essential component in effective communication. Feedback involves the response or reaction provided by the receiver back to the sender, enabling clarification, understanding, and improvement in subsequent interactions.

 

The other options—ambiguity, lack of trust, and distortions in communication—are recognized barriers that can hinder effective communication:

 

Ambiguity creates confusion or uncertainty due to unclear or vague messages, leading to misunderstandings.

Lack of trust between communicators can impede the exchange of information, as trust is essential for open and transparent communication.

Distortions in communication involve the intentional or unintentional manipulation, alteration, or misrepresentation of information, leading to a loss of accuracy or meaning in the message.

Question 28
Which of the following statements is not true? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.One sided messages work best with audiences those are initially predisposed to Communicator’s position.
  • B.Two sided arguments work best with audiences who are similar and not opposed.
  • C.Two sided messages tend to be more effective with better educated audiences.
  • D.Two sided messages tend to be more effective with audiences those are likely to be exposed to counter propaganda.
Correct Answer: Two sided arguments work best with audiences who are similar and not opposed.

The statement that is not true among the options provided is (B) Two sided arguments work best with audiences who are similar and not opposed.

 

The effectiveness of two-sided arguments is actually higher when addressing audiences who are initially opposed or skeptical. Presenting both sides of an argument allows the communicator to acknowledge opposing viewpoints, which can enhance credibility and persuasion, especially with an audience that might be initially opposed to the communicator's position.

Question 29
Which among the following is not a physical barrier of communication? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.Poor vocabulary
  • B.Noise
  • C.Improper time
  • D.Overload information
Correct Answer: Poor vocabulary

Among the options provided, "Poor vocabulary" is not a physical barrier to communication. Instead, it falls under the category of linguistic or semantic barriers, related to the understanding and usage of language.

 

The other options—Noise, Improper time, and Overload information—are considered physical barriers:

Noise disrupts the communication process by interfering with the transmission or reception of the message. It can be external (such as loud sounds) or internal (mental distractions).

Improper time refers to situations where communication occurs at an inappropriate or inconvenient time, hindering effective message delivery or reception.

Overload information occurs when there's an excessive amount of information to process, leading to difficulties in understanding or retaining essential details.

 

Hence, the correct answer among the options provided is (A) Poor vocabulary, which is a linguistic or language-related barrier rather than a physical one.

Question 30
Which one of the following regarding the structural barriers to communication is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.Filtering and Inattention
  • B.Credibility and Attitude
  • C.Emotions and Time pressure
  • D.Status and Specialisation
Correct Answer: Status and Specialisation

Structural barriers to communication are related to the organization's structure, hierarchy, and how information flows within it. Among the options provided:

 

Filtering and Inattention are more associated with personal or individual barriers.

Credibility and Attitude pertain more to personal traits affecting how someone perceives or responds to communication.

Emotions and Time pressure are again related to personal or emotional barriers in the communication process.

 

However, (D) Status and Specialization align more closely with structural barriers. Status refers to hierarchical positions within an organization affecting communication channels and how information moves within the hierarchy. Specialization indicates how specific roles or specialized knowledge can limit or influence communication between different departments or individuals with specialized knowledge areas.

Question 31
Assertion A:‘Grapevine’ tends to be more active during periods of change, excitement, anxiety and sagging economic conditions.Reason R:Employees use this communication to fill in important information gaps and clarify management decisions.(UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.A is right and R is wrong.
  • B.A is wrong and R is right.
  • C.Both A and R are right and R explains A.
  • D.Both A and R are right but R does not explain A.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are right and R explains A.

Assertion (A) states that the 'grapevine' tends to be more active during periods of change, excitement, anxiety, and economic downturns. This is often observed in organizations, as during times of uncertainty or change, informal communication networks like the grapevine become more active. Employees seek information, share rumors, and try to make sense of the situation through these channels.

 

Reason (R) explains that employees use this form of communication, the grapevine, to fill in important information gaps and clarify management decisions. This is accurate as the grapevine often operates where formal communication lacks or where there is ambiguity. Employees resort to informal communication to seek clarification or to gather information that might not be readily available through official channels.

 

Hence, in this case, both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are correct, and Reason (R) indeed provides an explanation for Assertion (A), making (C) Both A and R are right and R explains A the correct choice.

Question 32
What is the correct sequence in “Hierarchy of Effects” Model in a communication situation? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)A. PreferencesB. PurchaseC. Awareness and knowledgeD. ConvictionE. LikingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.D, B, E, C, A
  • C.B, A, D, C, A
  • D.C, E, A, D, B
Correct Answer: C, E, A, D, B

Option D is the correct answer. The Hierarchy of Effects Model is a model in communication situation that tells advertisers to make an advertisement in such a way that the customer goes through all these 6 stages namely awareness, knowledge, liking, preference, conviction, and purchase.

 

It is created by Robert J Lavidge and Gary A Steiner in 1961, the hierarchy of effects model suggests six steps to consumer buying behaviour.

 

The Hierarchy of Effects Model outlines the stages consumers go through before making a purchase decision. Here's a detailed breakdown:

 

1. Awareness and Knowledge: The consumer becomes aware of the brand's existence and gains knowledge about its features, benefits, and availability.

 

2. Liking: Emotional connections are established, and consumers begin to develop a favorable attitude towards the brand.

 

3. Preference: The brand is preferred over competitors due to unique selling propositions or differentiators highlighted in marketing efforts.

 

4. Conviction: Doubts or hesitations in the consumer's mind regarding the brand are resolved, often through trials, free samples, or test drives.

 

5. Purchase: The final stage where the consumer decides to buy the product, considering factors like ease of purchase, availability, and overall experience.

 

So, the correct sequence from the provided options is (D) C, E, A, D, B. This sequence reflects the stages a consumer typically goes through in the process of making a purchase decision based on the Hierarchy of Effects Model.

Question 33
Match List I with List IIList I (Type of communication)A. Intra-personalB. Inter-personalC. GroupD. MassList II (Characteristics)I. Between personsII. within a small organizationIII. Large number of unknownaudienceIV. Within oneselfChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A - I, B - II, C - III, D - IV
  • B.A - II, B - III, C - IV, D - I
  • C.A - III, B - IV, C - I, D - II
  • D.A - IV, B - I, C - II, D - III
Correct Answer: A - IV, B - I, C - II, D - III

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Intra-personal communication can be defined as communication with one's self, and that may include self-talk, acts of imagination and visualization, and even recall and memory. – Recollection of past events

 

b. Inter-personal communication refers to communication between two or more people that knows each other. – Chatting with friends

 

c. Mass communication is the process of imparting and exchanging information through mass media to large segments of the population. – Addressing the nation over national TV network

 

d. Group communication refers to the messages that are exchanged by group members. The messages that are exchanged by group members provide evidence of the nature of the group. – Conducting a workshop for a select number of teachers.

Question 34
Match the following.List-I (Type of Communication)(a) Dyadic communication(b) Public communication(c) Organisational communication(d) Mass communicationList-II (Description)(i) Messages flow through a network of inter-dependent relationships(ii) Uses a medium to reach a large anonymous(iii) Provide equal opportunity to communicate(iv) Occurs within a formal and structured settingCodes
  • A.a - (ii), b - (iii), c - (iv), d - (i)
  • B.a - (iii), b - (iv), c - (i), d - (ii)
  • C.a - (iv), b - (i), c - (ii), d - (iii)
  • D.a - (i), b - (ii), c - (iii), d - (iv)
Correct Answer: a - (iii), b - (iv), c - (i), d - (ii)

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

1. Dyadic communication : Provide equal opportunity to communicate

Dyadic Communication is the form of verbal communication held face-to-face. This is the communication between two individuals related to their mutual ideas, behaviour, thoughts, perceptions, likes, dislikes etc.

 

2. Public communication : Occurs within a formal and structured setting

Public communication is a method to share program, ideas or propaganda to public. The main ideas is to give people a new information or knowledge. The message can come from personal, company and government.

 

3. Organizational communication : Messages flow through a network of inter-dependent relationships

Organizational communication means sending and receiving of messages among interrelated individuals within a particular environment or setting to achieve individual and common goals. Organizational communication is highly contextual and culturally dependent. Individuals in organizations transmit messages through face-to face, written, and mediated channels.

 

4. Mass communication : Uses a medium to reach a large anonymous

Mass communication is the process of imparting and exchanging information through mass media to large segments of the population. It is usually understood for relating to various forms of media, as these technologies are used for the dissemination of information, of which journalism and advertising are part.

Question 35
.) Match the following.List-I (Mode of Communication)(a) One-to-one(b) One-to-many(c) Many-to-many(d) One-to-noneList-II (Types of Communication)(i) Network (transactional)(ii) Intra-personal(iii) Inter-personal(iv) Mass communication especiallyprintCodes
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)- (iii), (c)- (iv), (d)- (i)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)- (iv), (c)- (i), (d)- (ii)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)- (i), (c)- (ii), (d)- (iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)- (iv), (c)- (i), (d)- (ii)

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. In one-to-one communication, there is a direct exchange of information between two individuals, which falls under the category of inter-personal communication.

 

b. One-to-many communication refers to the dissemination of information from one source to a large audience. This aligns with the concept of mass communication, especially in the context of print media.

 

c. Many-to-many communication involves multiple participants interacting with each other in a network-like structure. This type of communication is often transactional, as it involves the exchange of information among various individuals or groups.

 

d. One-to-none communication implies communication within oneself, such as self-reflection, self-talk, or personal contemplation. This falls under the category of intra-personal communication.

Question 36
Match the following.List-I (Authors)(a) Aristotle(b) Shannon and Weaver(c)Wilbur Schramm(d) David BerloList-II (Communication concepts)(i) SMCR - Sender, Message, Channel - Receiver - Model(ii) Circular Communication(iii) Speaker - Centred Communication(iv) Top-down, Linear CommunicationCodes
  • A.a - (i), b - (ii), c - (iii), d - (iv)
  • B.a - (ii), b - (iii), c - (iv), d - (i)
  • C.a - (iii), b - (iv), c - (ii), d - (i)
  • D.a - (iv), b - (i), c - (iii), d - (ii)
Correct Answer: a - (iii), b - (iv), c - (ii), d - (i)

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Aristotle's communication theory emphasizes the role of the speaker or communicator in the communication process. It focuses on the speaker's ability to effectively deliver the message and persuade the audience.

 

b. Shannon and Weaver's communication model, known as the SMCR model, stands for Sender, Message, Channel, and Receiver. It represents a linear communication process where the sender encodes a message, which is then transmitted through a channel and decoded by the receiver.

 

c. Wilbur Schramm's communication theory emphasizes the interactive and circular nature of communication. It highlights that communication involves a continuous exchange of messages between the sender and receiver, with feedback playing a crucial role.

 

d. David Berlo expanded upon Shannon and Weaver's model and developed his own communication model, known as the SMCR model. It emphasizes the key components of the communication process: Sender, Message, Channel, and Receiver. According to this model, effective communication occurs when the sender encodes the message using appropriate symbols, selects an appropriate channel for transmission, and the receiver successfully decodes and understands the message.

Question 37
Match List I with List IIList Ia. Prayer in silenceb. Teacher talking to students outside the classroomc. The CEO of a company issues a circular to his subordinatesd. Rumour mongering among employees of an organizationList IIi. Vertical communicationii. Grapevineiii. Intra-personal communicationiv. Group communicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • B.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Vertical communication is a type of flow of information between members of organisation who are on different levels of its hierarchy. It can be used both in a downward and upward direction. - The CEO of a company issues a circular to his subordinates

 

b. Grapevine communication is a form of informal communication, operates both in internal and external informal channels which can contribute to and benefit the organization. Therefore, it is found in all organizations. It does not follow any prescribed or predetermined rule and spreads any information quickly. - Rumour mongering among employees of an organization

 

c. Intra-personal communication can be defined as communication with one's self, and that may include self-talk, acts of imagination and visualization, and even recall and memory. – Prayer in silence

 

d. Group communication refers to the messages that are exchanged by group members. The messages that are exchanged by group members provide evidence of the nature of the group. – Teacher talking to students outside the classroom.

Question 38
Match the following types of communication with their distinguishing examplesList I (Types of communication)(a) Formal Communication(b) Informal Communication(c) Outward Communication(d) Inward CommunicationList II (Distinguishing examples)(i) Government agencies(ii) Circular(iii) Memos(iv) Group chainChoose your answer from the following options:
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Formal communication refers to official or structured communication within organizations, and memos are a common example of formal communication.

b. Informal communication refers to casual or unofficial communication between individuals or groups, and group chain is an example of informal communication.

c. Outward communication refers to communication directed outward from an organization, such as government agencies communicating with the public.

d. Inward communication refers to communication directed inward to an organization, and circulars are an example of inward communication.

Question 39
Auniversity teachersmakes a very effective expository presentation in his/her class without caring for its effect on the student. This is an example of a/an:
  • A.Linear Communication Model
  • B.Authoritarian Communication Model
  • C.Interactive Communication Model
  • D.Transactional Communication Model
Correct Answer: Linear Communication Model

In Linear model, communication is considered one way process where sender is the only one who sends message and receiver doesn’t give feedback or response. The message signal is encoded and transmitted through channel in presence of noise. The sender is more prominent in linear model of communication. The given example is Linear Communication.

Question 40
A teacher decides to form six groups of students and assigns a sub – theme to each group for discussion and reporting. Which kind of communication model will best describe his/her strategy in this regard?
  • A.Transactional model
  • B.Interactional model
  • C.Horizontal model
  • D.Linear model
Correct Answer: Transactional model

Transactional Model - The transactional model shows that the elements in communication are interdependent. Each person in the communication act is both a speaker and a listener, and can be simultaneously sending and receiving messages. The model implies:

  • “Transactional” means that communication is an ongoing and continuously changing process;
  • In any transactional process, each element exists in relation to all the other elements. There is this interdependence where there can be no source without a receiver and no message without a source;
  • Each person in the communication process reacts depending on factors such as their background, prior experiences, attitudes, cultural beliefs and self-esteem.
Question 41
Imagine you are working in an educational institution where people are of equal status. Which method of communication is best suited and normally employed in such a context?
  • A.Horizontal communication
  • B.Vertical communication
  • C.Corporate communication
  • D.Cross communication
Correct Answer: Horizontal communication

Horizontal communication refers to communication that takes place between individuals or groups at the same hierarchical level or with similar roles and responsibilities. It is characterized by a free flow of information, ideas, and feedback among colleagues or peers. In this type of communication, there is a sense of equality and collaboration, as everyone is considered equal in terms of their status and authority.

 

In an educational institution, teachers, staff members, and students often engage in horizontal communication to exchange information, share ideas, collaborate on projects, and address common concerns. This form of communication promotes teamwork, cooperation, and a sense of belonging among the individuals involved.

Question 42
The term ‘grapevine’ is also known as:
  • A.Downward communication
  • B.Informal communication
  • C.Upward communication
  • D.Horizontal communication
Correct Answer: Informal communication

'Grapevine' communication is also known as Informal Communication. Grapevine is an informal, unofficial and personal communication channel or system that takes place within the organization as a result of rumor and gossip. It is a complex web of oral information flow linking all the members of the organization.

Question 43
Which of the following can be categorized as non-verbal communication?A. Pleasant voiceB. PosturesC. GesturesD. Facial expressionsE. Vociferous greetingsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C
  • B.B, C and E
  • C.C, D and E
  • D.B, C and D
Correct Answer: B, C and D

Non-verbal communication refers to the transmission of messages or information without the use of spoken or written words. It is conveyed through various non-verbal cues and behaviors.

 

a. Postures: Postures or body positions can convey a range of messages and attitudes. Different postures can indicate interest, attentiveness, relaxation, defensiveness, and more.

b. Gestures: Gestures involve using hand movements, body movements, or facial expressions to convey meaning. They can include gestures such as pointing, waving, nodding, or shrugging, among others.

c. Facial expressions: Facial expressions play a significant role in non-verbal communication. Different facial expressions convey emotions, attitudes, and reactions. For example, a smile can indicate happiness or friendliness, while a frown can indicate sadness or disapproval.

Question 44
Which of the following can be used to overcome communication barriers in an organization?a. Unlimited use of grapevineb. Sectionalised and preferred feedbackc. Action oriented communicationd. Proper use of languagee. Inter personal relationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, c
  • B.b, c, d
  • C.c, d, e
  • D.a, d, e
Correct Answer: c, d, e

To overcome communication barriers in an organization, the following approaches can be used:

 

a. Action-oriented communication: This approach emphasizes clear and specific communication that focuses on actions, tasks, and objectives. It helps to eliminate ambiguity and ensures that communication is goal-oriented and results-driven.

 

b. Proper use of language: Using language effectively and appropriately is essential for effective communication. This includes using clear and concise language, avoiding jargon or technical terms that may not be understood by everyone, and being mindful of cultural and language differences.

 

c. Interpersonal relations: Building and maintaining positive interpersonal relations within the organization is crucial for effective communication. This involves fostering trust, respect, and open communication among team members, promoting collaboration, and encouraging active listening and understanding.

Question 45
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)List – Ia. Cognitive bias in which one trait of a person influences overall judgement about him.b. Meaningless talk or writing familiar only to a group or a professionc. Converting the message into symbols by senderd. Manipulating information to make it appear favourable to receiverList – IIi. Jargonii. Halo Effectiii. Encodingiv. Filtering
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • D.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv

The matching of terms from List I to their descriptions in List II involves concepts related to communication and cognitive biases:

 

Halo Effect (a-ii): This is a cognitive bias in which one positive trait or aspect of a person influences our overall judgment of that individual. For instance, if someone is considered physically attractive, we might also assume they have other positive qualities.

 

Jargon (b-i): Jargon refers to specialized language or terminology that is used within a specific group, profession, or field. It's often technical or difficult for outsiders to understand.

 

Encoding (c-iii): This is the process of converting a message or information into symbols, such as words, gestures, or images, by the sender. It's a crucial step in the communication process where thoughts or ideas are transformed into a format that can be transmitted and understood.

 

Filtering (d-iv): Filtering involves manipulating or altering information to present it in a way that appears favorable or acceptable to the receiver. It typically involves selective presentation or distortion of information to achieve a specific outcome or response.

Question 46
‘Gang plank’ breaks which one of the following?(UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Cross Communications
  • B.Mass communication
  • C.Scalar chain
  • D.Vertical communication
Correct Answer: Scalar chain

In management, Henri Fayol introduced the concept of the "scalar chain," which refers to the hierarchical levels in an organization where communication typically flows through a chain of command from top to bottom or vice versa.

 

The term "gang plank" was introduced by Fayol to address a limitation within the scalar chain. It refers to a direct communication link between individuals at the same hierarchical level, bypassing the usual chain of command. This direct link is particularly useful in situations where immediate or emergency communication between peers at the same level is necessary.

 

Therefore, the correct answer to the question would indeed be (C) Scalar chain, as the introduction of the gang plank concept by Fayol aimed to address the delays or limitations that could arise from strictly adhering to communication solely through the scalar chain.

Quiz Attempt #118949

Total Questions: 44
Question 1
Which of the following arethe key features of linear model of communication?A. One way communicationB. Manipulated feedbackC. Absence of noiseD. Used for mass communicationE. Sender centric communicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C
  • B.B, C, D
  • C.D, C, E
  • D.A, D, E
Correct Answer: A, D, E

The key features of the linear model of communication are as follows:

 

a. One-way communication: In the linear model, communication is seen as a one-way process where information flows linearly from the sender to the receiver. There is no active feedback or response from the receiver to the sender.

 

b. Used for mass communication: The linear model is often used to describe mass communication processes, where a single message is transmitted to a large audience. It emphasizes the dissemination of information from the sender to a large number of receivers.

 

c. Sender-centric communication: The linear model places the primary focus on the sender or the source of the message. It emphasizes the sender's role in encoding and transmitting the message, while the receiver's role is seen as passive.

Question 2
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Communication has the power to define, persuade and inform issues and events to the people.Statement II:Communication cannot serve as a tool of demarcation among people.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false.

Statement I: This statement is true. Communication indeed has the power to define, persuade, and inform people about issues and events. Through communication, information is disseminated, opinions are shaped, and people are influenced in their understanding and perspectives.

 

Statement II: This statement is false. Communication can indeed serve as a tool of demarcation among people. Different communication channels, messages, and narratives can lead to divisions and distinctions among individuals and groups based on their access to information, beliefs, ideologies, and perspectives.

Question 3
The golden rules that communicators should follow are:A. They should be aloofB. They should take sidesC. They must be heardD. They must be understoodE. They must be appreciatedChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, C, D only
  • C.D, E, A only
  • D.C, D, E only
Correct Answer: C, D, E only

The correct answer is (D) The golden rules that communicators should follow are:

 

(i) They must be heard: Effective communication involves ensuring that your message is received and acknowledged by the intended audience. Being heard means that your message reaches the receiver, and they pay attention to it.

 

(ii) They must be understood: Communication is successful when the receiver comprehends the message in the same way it was intended by the sender. It is essential to use clear and concise language, provide relevant explanations, and consider the receiver's background and knowledge to promote understanding.

 

(iii) They must be appreciated: Communication becomes more effective when the receiver values and appreciates the message. This can be achieved by presenting information in an engaging and compelling manner, highlighting the benefits or relevance to the receiver, and addressing their needs or interests.

Question 4
The sequence of stages of active listening is:A. UnderstandingB. RememberingC. RespondingD. ReceivingE. EvaluatingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, E, D
  • B.C, A, D, B, E
  • C.D, A, E, B, C
  • D.B, C, E, D, A
Correct Answer: D, A, E, B, C

The sequence of stages of active listening typically follows this order:

 

1. Receiving: The first stage of active listening is receiving. It involves being physically present and paying attention to the speaker. Receiving includes using your senses to perceive the verbal and non-verbal cues of the speaker, such as their words, tone of voice, facial expressions, and body language.

 

2. Understanding: After receiving the message, the listener moves on to the stage of understanding. This stage involves comprehending the message, interpreting its meaning, and grasping the speaker's intended message. It requires actively processing and making sense of the information being conveyed.

 

3. Evaluating: The next stage is evaluating. At this stage, the listener critically assesses the information, analyzes its validity, considers alternative perspectives, and forms opinions or judgments based on the message and its content. Evaluating allows the listener to think critically and engage in a deeper analysis of the information.

 

4. Remembering: Remembering is the stage where the listener retains the information and stores it in memory for future reference. It involves recalling and retaining key details, main ideas, and important points from the speaker's message.

 

5. Responding: The final stage of active listening is responding. This stage involves providing feedback or a response to the speaker. It can include verbal responses, such as asking questions, providing comments, or offering reflections, as well as non-verbal responses, such as nodding or maintaining eye contact. Responding shows engagement, confirms understanding, and encourages further communication.

Question 5
Which of the following are the finer points of effective listening?A. Not observing the speakerB. Not reflecting back on what is saidC. Staying indifferentD. Asking questions for clarityE. Focusing attention on what is saidChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, C and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

The finer points of effective listening are:

 

a. Staying indifferent: This refers to maintaining a neutral and unbiased attitude while listening. It involves withholding judgment and allowing the speaker to express their thoughts without interruption or bias.

 

b. Asking questions for clarity: This involves seeking clarification from the speaker to ensure a clear understanding of their message. Asking relevant questions can help clarify any ambiguities, fill in gaps, and gain deeper insights into the speaker's perspective.

 

c. Focusing attention on what is said: This entails giving undivided attention to the speaker and actively concentrating on their words and non-verbal cues. It involves minimizing distractions, such as internal thoughts or external disturbances, and being fully present in the moment to comprehend the message effectively

Question 6
Identify the correct sequence of information processing in communicationA. InputB. OutputC. Data entryD. ProcessingE. StorageChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, E, D, C
  • B.B, D, E, A, C
  • C.C, A, D, E, B
  • D.A, C, D, E, B
Correct Answer: C, A, D, E, B

. Let's discuss the sequence of information processing in communication:

 

1. Data entry: The first step in information processing is data entry. This involves the input of raw data or information into a system or medium for further processing.

2. Input: Once the data is entered, it is received or inputted into the communication system. This can occur through various means such as typing, speaking, or receiving signals.

3. Processing: After the input stage, the data undergoes processing or transformation. This involves analyzing, organizing, and manipulating the data to derive meaningful information or to perform specific operations.

4. Storage: Once the data is processed, it can be stored or saved for future use or reference. Storage allows for the retention of information over time.

5. Output: The final stage in the sequence is the output. This refers to the presentation, display, or delivery of processed information or the result of the communication process. Output can take various forms such as displaying on a screen, printing, or transmitting to another medium or recipient.

Question 7
Identify the correct sequence for successful communication.
  • A.Sender → Encode message → Channel → Decode message → Audience → Feedback
  • B.Sender → Encode message → Audience → Channel → Decode message → Feedback
  • C.Sender → Encode message → Decode message → Channel → Audience → Feedback
  • D.Sender → Encode message → Channel → Decode message → Feedback → Audience
Correct Answer: Sender → Encode message → Audience → Channel → Decode message → Feedback

The sequence for successful communication is as follows:

 

1. Sender: The communication process starts with a sender or communicator who has a message to convey.

2. Encode message: The sender encodes or formulates the message into a format that can be transmitted to the audience. This involves choosing the appropriate words, symbols, or nonverbal cues to convey the intended meaning.

3. Audience: The encoded message is directed towards the intended audience or receiver of the communication. The audience is the target of the message and plays a crucial role in the communication process.

4. Channel: The message is transmitted through a chosen channel or medium, such as face-to-face conversation, phone call, email, or social media platforms. The channel serves as the means of transmitting the message from the sender to the receiver.

5. Decode message: The audience receives the message and decodes or interprets the encoded message based on their understanding, knowledge, and context. They extract meaning from the message and try to make sense of it.

6. Feedback: Once the message is decoded by the audience, they provide feedback to the sender, which can be in the form of verbal or nonverbal responses. Feedback helps the sender understand how well the message was received and understood by the audience.

Question 8
Match List I with List II.List I (Elements of Communication)A. SourceB. ReceiverC. MessageD. ChannelList II (Characteristic feature)I. Means used to convey the messageII. Set of verbal and nonverbal cues from a sourceIII. A person who interprets the messageIV. A person or an event which provides verbal/non-verbal cues.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A‐II, B‐I, C‐IV, D‐III
  • B.A‐I, B‐II, C‐III, D‐IV
  • C.A‐III, B‐IV, C‐I, D‐II
  • D.A‐IV, B‐III, C‐II, D‐I
Correct Answer: A‐IV, B‐III, C‐II, D‐I

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Source: The source is the originator or sender of the communication. This is because the source generates the message and communicates it through various cues such as spoken words, body language, or gestures.

 

b. Receiver: The receiver is the person or entity who interprets the message sent by the source. The receiver receives and processes the message, trying to understand its meaning and significance.

 

c. Message: The message refers to the content or information being communicated. The message can include spoken words, written text, visual signals, or any other form of communication cues used by the source to convey information.

 

d. Channel: The channel represents the medium or means through which the message is transmitted from the source to the receiver. The channel can include various forms such as face-to-face conversation, telephone, email, or any other communication medium utilized for transmitting the message.

Question 9
Match List I with List IIList I (Concept of Power Communication)A. Legitimate powerB. Referent powerC. Reward powerD. Expert powerList II (Description of feature)I. Specialized knowledgeII. By virtue of positionIII. When others feel to be like youIV. Control over what others seekChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A ‐ I, B ‐ II, C ‐ III, D ‐ IV
  • B.A ‐ III, B ‐ IV, C ‐ I, D ‐ II
  • C.A ‐ IV, B ‐ I, C ‐ II, D ‐ III
  • D.A ‐ II, B ‐ III, C ‐ IV, D ‐ I
Correct Answer: A ‐ II, B ‐ III, C ‐ IV, D ‐ I

Correct answer is D.

 

a. Legitimate power: Legitimate power is based on the authority or position one holds in an organization or social structure. It is associated with formal authority and the ability to exert control or influence due to one's position.

 

b. Referent power: Referent power is based on others' identification, admiration, or desire to be like the person who possesses the power. It is built on charisma, trust, and personal connections.

 

c. Reward power: Reward power is derived from the ability to provide rewards or incentives to others. It involves controlling access to desired resources or outcomes.

 

d. Expert power: Expert power is based on specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise that others perceive as valuable. It is derived from a person's competence and credibility in a specific domain.

Question 10
The sequence of communication zones based on individual distances is:A. Public zoneB. Intimate zoneC. Personal zoneD. Social zoneChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.B, C, D, A
  • C.C, D, A, B
  • D.D, A, B, C
Correct Answer: B, C, D, A

The four zones of interpersonal space are:

The intimate zone is within touching distance, from actually touching to about two feet. This is the space reserved for people who genuinely care about each other.

The personal zone is from two to four feet. It’s used for discussions that are private and not meant to be overheard.

The social zone is four to twelve feet apart. This is the space used for public and casual social conversations. It allows others to enter into the group.

The public zone is more than twelve feet. Public speakers and important figures use space to distance themselves from their audience (and establish authority, since demanding more space is a power signal)

Question 11
Identify the correct sequence of the following:
  • A.Source, channel, message, receiver
  • B.Source, receiver, channel, message
  • C.Source, message, receiver, channel
  • D.Source, message, channel, receiver
Correct Answer: Source, message, channel, receiver

The correct sequence is SOURCE, MESSAGE, CHANNEL, RECEIVER.

 

 

The correct sequence can be seen in the diagram.

In the communication process, the correct sequence is as follows:

 

(i) Source: The source refers to the person or entity that initiates the communication. It encodes the message, which means transforming thoughts, ideas, or information into a form that can be transmitted.

 

(ii) Message: The message is the content or information that is being communicated. It can be in various forms such as verbal, written, visual, or non-verbal. The message carries the intended meaning from the source to the receiver.

 

(iii) Channel: The channel is the medium or method through which the message is transmitted from the source to the receiver. It can include various communication channels like face-to-face conversation, written letters, phone calls, emails, or social media platforms.

 

(iv) Receiver: The receiver is the person or entity for whom the message is intended. The receiver decodes the message, which means interpreting and understanding the meaning conveyed by the source. The receiver plays an important role in the communication process by providing feedback and responding to the message.

 

The correct sequence of (D) Source, message, channel, receiver reflects the flow of communication from the source, through the message and channel, to the receiver. This sequence ensures that the message is effectively transmitted and understood.

Question 12
An example of asynchronous mediais
  • A.The television
  • B.The radio
  • C.The cinema
  • D.The newspaper
Correct Answer: The newspaper

Asynchronous media refers to forms of communication where the sender and receiver are not required to be engaged in the communication simultaneously. Newspapers fall under this category because readers can access and read the content at their own convenience, without being tied to a specific broadcast schedule.

Question 13
The important features of the transactional model of communication areA. Feedback is repetitive.B. It is mostly used for inter-personal communication.C. The senders and the receivers of messages can inter-change their roles.D. Feedback is simultaneous.E. The heavy dose of noise provides a message.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

The transactional model of communication emphasizes the dynamic and simultaneous nature of communication. It recognizes that both parties (sender and receiver) are actively involved in the communication process, and roles can interchange. Simultaneous feedback and interaction are central to this model.

Question 14
The key features ofthe interaction model of communication are:A. It is atwo wayprocessB. The physical context of communication is unimportantC. The psychological context of communicationD. Feedback is not a response to the message receivedE. It is less message focusedChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C
  • B.B, C, D
  • C.A, C, E
  • D.C, D, E
Correct Answer: A, C, E

The key features of the interaction model of communication are:

 

a. The interaction model of communication emphasizes the importance of feedback and response in the communication process. It recognizes that communication involves an exchange of messages between the sender and receiver, with both parties actively participating and contributing to the interaction.

 

b. The interaction model considers the psychological aspects of communication, including the mental and emotional states of the sender and receiver. It recognizes that individuals bring their own perceptions, beliefs, values, and attitudes to the communication process, which can influence the interpretation and understanding of the message.

 

c. Unlike other models of communication that primarily focus on the transmission of a message from sender to receiver, the interaction model places greater emphasis on the dynamic nature of communication and the importance of the feedback and response loop. It recognizes that communication is not solely about the message itself, but also about the ongoing interaction, interpretation, and negotiation of meaning between the participants.

Question 15
A leave application from a clerk to the principal of the institution, is an example of:
  • A.Downward communication
  • B.Upwardcommunication
  • C.Horizontalcommunication
  • D.Generalcommunication
Correct Answer: Upwardcommunication

Upward communication is the line of communication through which subordinates can convey information, to their seniors. Hence, a leave application from a clerk to the principal of the institution, is an example of Upward communication.

Question 16
What arethe key features of transactional model of communication?A. Absence of noiseB. Extensively used in interpersonal communicationC. Feedback is a new messageD. Role exchange by encoder and decoderE. Encoder and decoder discrimination is the orderChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

The key features of the transactional model of communication are:

 

a. Extensively used in interpersonal communication: The transactional model of communication is primarily used to understand and explain interpersonal communication, which occurs between two or more individuals.

 

b. Feedback is a new message: In the transactional model, feedback is not simply a response or reaction to the original message but is considered as a new message. Feedback plays an active role in the communication process by influencing the ongoing interaction between the participants.

 

c. Role exchange by encoder and decoder: Unlike other models where the roles of encoder (sender) and decoder (receiver) are fixed, the transactional model allows for role exchange between the participants. In this model, both participants can simultaneously take on the role of encoder and decoder, actively encoding and decoding messages.

Question 17
The grapevine communication is often driven by:
  • A.External professional agencies
  • B.Competing organizations
  • C.Top management of an organization
  • D.Social networks of employees
Correct Answer: Social networks of employees

Grapevine communication is a form of informal communication within an organization. It is described as an outlet for people's imagination and is open to interpretation. Grapevine communication is driven by the social networks of employees within the organization.

 

Grapevines are of two types: gossip and rumors. These types of communication often spread through social networks within the organization. Employees share information, speculations, and opinions with each other through informal channels, bypassing formal communication channels.

Question 18
Identifythe correct sequence of the elements of communication set by Aristotle:A. SpeechB. SpeakerC. AudienceD. OccasionE. EffectChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, B, C, E
  • B.D, B, A, E, C
  • C.C, D, A, E, B
  • D.B, A, D, C, E
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C, E

In Aristotle's communication model, the sequence of elements is as follows:

 

1. Speaker: The speaker is considered the central figure in the communication process. They have the responsibility of delivering the speech and influencing the audience through their public speaking skills. The effectiveness of the communication largely depends on the speaker's ability to convey their message.

 

2. Speech: The speech itself is a crucial element in communication. The speaker must organize and prepare the speech beforehand, considering the target audience and the occasion. The content of the speech should be carefully designed to deliver a clear and persuasive message to the audience.

 

3. Occasion: The occasion refers to the context or situation in which the communication takes place. The speaker must take into account the specific occasion or event for which they are delivering the speech. The nature of the occasion may influence the tone, content, and delivery style of the speech.

 

4. Audience: The audience is an important element in communication as they are the receivers of the message. In Aristotle's model, the audience is considered passive and influenced by the speech. The speaker's goal is to effectively engage and persuade the audience through their speech.

 

5. Effect: The effect refers to the impact or influence that the speech has on the audience. The ultimate goal of communication is to achieve the desired effect on the audience, whether it is to inform, persuade, entertain, or inspire. The success of the communication is determined by the effect it has on the audience.

 

Question 19
Match List I with List IIList I (Type of Communication)A. Intra‐personalB. Group communicationC. TransactionalD. MassiveList II (Example)I. Face‐to‐faceII. Satellite televisionIII. MeditationIV. Board meetingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A‐I, B‐III, C‐IV, D‐II
  • B.A‐II, B‐IV, C‐III, D‐I
  • C.A‐III, B‐IV, C‐I, D‐II
  • D.A‐IV, B‐I, C‐II, D‐III
Correct Answer: A‐III, B‐IV, C‐I, D‐II

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Intra-personal communication refers to communication that occurs within an individual's own mind or thoughts. It involves self-reflection, self-talk, or inner dialogue. Meditation is an example of intra-personal communication as it involves focusing one's attention inward and engaging in self-reflection or mental contemplation.

 

b. Group communication refers to the exchange of information, ideas, and opinions among members of a group. A board meeting, where individuals from a board of directors come together to discuss and make decisions about organizational matters, is an example of group communication. It involves multiple participants interacting and sharing information within a structured setting.

 

c. Transactional communication refers to a dynamic and simultaneous exchange of messages between communicators. It emphasizes the mutual influence and co-creation of meaning between participants. Face-to-face communication, where individuals interact directly and engage in real-time conversation, is an example of transactional communication. It involves active listening, feedback, and nonverbal cues.

 

d. Massive communication refers to the dissemination of information to a large and diverse audience, often through mass media channels. Satellite television is an example of massive communication as it allows for the broadcast of television programs and content to a widespread audience through satellite signals. It reaches a large number of viewers simultaneously.

Question 20
Match List I with List IIList I (Type of communication)A. PhaticB. FeedbackC. Meta messageD. Lateral communicationList II (Description)I. Decoder becomes encoderII. Communication about communicationIII. Between equalsIV. To greetChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Phatic - This type of communication is primarily used for social or relational purposes, such as greetings or small talk. It corresponds to the description "To greet."

 

b. Feedback - Feedback refers to the process of providing a response or reaction to a message received. It involves the recipient becoming the sender or encoder of the feedback.

 

c. Meta message - Meta message refers to communication about communication itself. It involves messages that convey information about the underlying message or the way it is being delivered. It corresponds to the description "Communication about communication."

 

d. Lateral communication - Lateral communication refers to communication that takes place between equals or peers, without the hierarchical structure typically present in formal communication. It corresponds to the description "Between equals."

Question 21
Which of the following is considered unethical communication?
  • A.Use of alternative source of information
  • B.Not revealing the source of information
  • C.Propaganda
  • D.Non‐commercial publicity
Correct Answer: Propaganda

Ethical communication refers to the practice of communicating in a truthful, honest, and responsible manner, while respecting the rights and dignity of others.

 

Propaganda refers to the dissemination of biased or misleading information with the intention to shape public opinion, promote a specific ideology, or manipulate people's beliefs and behaviors. It often involves the use of persuasive techniques, exaggeration, manipulation of emotions, and selective presentation of facts to influence and control the audience.

Question 22
A general code of conduct circulated among the employees of an institution is an example of:
  • A.Downward communication
  • B.Lateral communication
  • C.Horizontal communication
  • D.Upward communication
Correct Answer: Downward communication

Downward communication is the act of relaying important information in a company or organization from higher levels to lower levels. Hence, a general code of conduct circulated among the employees of an institution is an example of Downward communication.

Question 23
Match List I with List IIList I (Types of Communication)A. SynchronousB. AsynchronousC. ParticipatoryD. AuthoritarianList II (Types of communication Example)I. Newspaper readingII. Face-to-faceIII. Head of the organization to employeesIV. Boardroom meetingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A -I ,B -III ,C -II ,D -IV
  • B.A -IV ,B -I ,C -II ,D -III
  • C.A -II ,B -I ,C -IV ,D -III
  • D.A -III ,B -IV ,C -I ,D -II
Correct Answer: A -II ,B -I ,C -IV ,D -III

Here's the matching of List I with List II:

 

a. Synchronous communication refers to communication that occurs in real-time, where participants interact and exchange messages immediately. An example of synchronous communication is face-to-face interaction, where individuals communicate directly with each other.

 

b. Asynchronous communication, on the other hand, refers to communication that does not occur in real-time. Participants do not need to be present simultaneously to exchange messages. An example of asynchronous communication is reading a newspaper, where individuals receive information but do not engage in immediate interaction.

 

c. Participatory communication involves active involvement and engagement of participants. It emphasizes collaboration and joint decision-making. An example of participatory communication is a boardroom meeting, where participants actively contribute to discussions and decision-making processes.

 

d. Authoritarian communication is characterized by a hierarchical structure and a top-down flow of information. The head of the organization communicating with employees represents this type of communication, where the leader or authority figure holds the primary role in conveying information and instructions.

Question 24
Identify the CORRECT sequence of the following communication forms:1. Mass2. Public3. Group4. Inter‐personal5. Intra‐personalChoose the correct answer from the options given below
  • A.1, 4, 5, 2, 3
  • B.4, 5, 2, 3, 1
  • C.5, 4, 3, 2, 1
  • D.2, 3, 1, 4, 5
Correct Answer: 5, 4, 3, 2, 1

The sequence of communication forms is:

 

1. Intra-personal communication refers to the communication that occurs within an individual's own mind or self-talk.

2. Inter-personal communication involves the exchange of information and interaction between two or more individuals.

3. Group communication involves communication within a small group or team where multiple individuals interact and share information.

4. Public communication refers to the communication between a speaker or sender and a large audience or public.

5. Mass communication involves the transmission of messages or information to a large and diverse audience through various media channels.

Question 25
Peer‐to‐peer communication is:
  • A.Horizontal
  • B.Convoluted
  • C.Non‐transactional
  • D.Authoritarian
Correct Answer: Horizontal

Peer-to-peer communication refers to communication that occurs between individuals at the same hierarchical level or status. It is characterized by a more equal distribution of power and authority compared to hierarchical or authoritarian communication.

 

In peer-to-peer communication, individuals have similar roles, responsibilities, and levels of expertise, allowing for more open and collaborative exchange of ideas and information. It often involves active listening, mutual respect, and shared decision-making.

Question 26
More and more informal exchanges within a group to resolve conflicts is an example of:
  • A.Vertical communication
  • B.Horizontal communication
  • C.Risk communication
  • D.Personal communication
Correct Answer: Horizontal communication

Horizontal communication refers to the exchange of information, ideas, and feedback between individuals or groups at the same level of hierarchy or status within an organization or group. It involves informal interactions and collaborative discussions among peers, colleagues, or team members.

 

In the given scenario, when a group engages in more and more informal exchanges to resolve conflicts, it signifies horizontal communication. The group members are actively communicating with each other to address and resolve conflicts, without relying on formal channels or hierarchical structures.

Question 27
The main challenges of grapevine communication are:1. Its formal nature2. Distortion3. Misunderstanding4. Source anonymity5. ConformityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1, 2 and 3 only
  • B.2, 3 and 4 only
  • C.3, 4 and 5 only
  • D.1, 3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 2, 3 and 4 only

The challenges of grapevine communication include:

 

a. Distortion: Grapevine communication is prone to distortion as information passes through multiple individuals and can be altered or misinterpreted along the way. Rumors and gossip can spread, leading to inaccuracies and misunderstandings.

 

b. Misunderstanding: Due to the informal nature of grapevine communication, there is a higher likelihood of misunderstandings arising. Lack of clarity, incomplete information, or personal biases can contribute to misunderstandings among individuals.

 

c. Source anonymity: Grapevine communication often lacks clear attribution of information, making it difficult to determine the original source. This anonymity can lead to a lack of accountability and reliability of the information being shared.

Question 28
Chatting on WhatsApp is an example of:
  • A.Synchronous communication
  • B.Asynchronous communication
  • C.Non‐verbal communication
  • D.Friendly communication
Correct Answer: Synchronous communication

Synchronous communications is that which takes place in real-time between two or more parties. Put simply; a synchronous communication exchange is an interactive, 'live' interchange between people.

 

Hence, chatting on WhatsApp is an example of synchronous communication.

Question 29
The communication between two or more persons who are subordinates working under the same person is an exampleof :
  • A.Lateral communication
  • B.Upward communication
  • C.Diagonal communication
  • D.Downward communication
Correct Answer: Lateral communication

Horizontal/Lateral communication is "the exchange, imparting or sharing of information, ideas or feelings between people within a community, peer groups, departments or units of an organization who are at or about the same hierarchical level as each other for the purpose of coordinating activities, efforts or fulfilling a common purpose or goal.

 

In the example given in the question, it is lateral communication.

Question 30
